item.title: Study | Angola and Mozambique exposed to Chinese slowdown
item.description: The slowdown in the Chinese economy and possible transformation of its growth model could have profound impacts on African countries, including Angola and Mozambique, warns in a report by the Rhodium Group think tank. “As China's economic model loses steam, African leaders will have to plan growth and economic transformation aware that their largest trading and investment partner could have a very different profile than it has had until now”, reads the analysis carried out by the group, based in New York. Angola is identified as one of the countries most sensitive to the evolution of the second largest economy in the world. China is one of the main destinations for Angolan crude and the report anticipates that Chinese imports of African oil are expected to stagnate or decline, as Beijing accelerates the energy transition, expands the fleet of electric vehicles and reduces the energy intensity of its economy. This scenario could put pressure on tax revenues, exports and Luanda's ability to honor its external debt, in a context in which the country already pays more to China in repayments than it receives in new loans. Mozambique may have a different trajectory. Although also exposed to Chinese demand for raw materials, the report anticipates a structurally robust demand for strategic minerals associated with the energy transition, such as graphite and other critical minerals, sectors in which Mozambique has been gaining relevance.

item.title: DSAMA | Authorities prepare for dry period
item.description: Local and Zhuhai authorities met on the 19th to discuss preventive water storage to combat saline intrusion, which will lead to a dry period until February. The meeting was held between the Bureau of Maritime and Water Affairs (DSAMA), the Zhuhai Water Affairs Bureau and Zhuhai Water Environment Holdings Group LTD. Taking into account the forecasts of water authorities in Mainland China, “the natural inflow to the Xi River basin is expected to be between 10 and 30 percent below the average between December 2025 and February 2026, indicating drier conditions than usual this winter and next spring”, is mentioned in the DSAMA statement. Taking this scenario into account, it was indicated that, currently, “effective storage capacity has reached 90 percent, exceeding the levels observed in the same period of previous years”, and “all reservoirs in Zhuhai are operating with high water levels”, with their maintenance completed before the arrival of this “dry period”. Susana Wong, director of DSAMA, said that “over the years, the Zhuhai Water Affairs Department has continuously strengthened its capacity to guarantee the supply of raw water to Macau”. The official also said, regarding the emergency water supply capacity in Macau, that “the project to expand the Seac Pai Van Reservoir is ongoing and its completion is scheduled for 2028”, and “after completion, Macau's water consumption autonomy will increase to 12 days”. The meeting also served to discuss the price of raw water for the years 2026 to 2028, taking into account that “the Guangdong-Macao Water Supply Agreement provides for a three-yearly adjustment of the price of raw water supplied by Zhuhai to Macau, with 2026 being the next year of adjustment”.

item.title: L’Arc | SJM obtains authorization for direct exploration
item.description: The concessionaire, SJM Resorts, obtained authorization to operate the Casino L’Arc Macau, under the form of direct management and exploitation, from 2am on December 30th. The announcement was made by the Gaming Inspection and Coordination Directorate (DICJ) and was expected after an agreement for the acquisition of the casino by the concessionaire was announced. “Taking into account that the three-year ‘transitional period’ granted to ‘satellite casinos’ ends at the end of the current year, SJM submitted a request to cease operating Casino L’Arc Macau as a “satellite casino” from 01:59 on 30 December, which was authorized by the Macao SAR Government”, it was stated. “After analysis and consideration, the Macao SAR Government considered that the request meets the requirements and conditions of the respective legislation, and therefore granted authorization to the aforementioned request”, it was added. The DICJ also promises to monitor the operation of the casino.

item.title: Death | French actress Brigitte Bardot dies aged 91
item.description: Brigitte Bardot, one of the biggest stars in world cinema, passed away yesterday at the age of 91. The actress had been admitted to the hospital in the city of Toulon, in the south of France, since November. In a statement, the Brigitte Bardot Foundation announced her death with “immense sadness”, describing her as a “world-renowned actress and singer, who chose to abandon her prestigious career to dedicate her life and energy to animal welfare and her foundation”. Known for her enormous impact on cinema in the 1950s, «BB», as she was widely called in France, was an essential ingredient of French culture and quickly became an icon after her first role in Le Trou Normand (1952). Two more films followed in 1952, when she married director Roger Vadim. A year later, Bardot conquered Hollywood and the United States, and her popularity as one of the sexiest women in the world was firmly established. Brigitte Bardot continued to act in a total of 28 films over two decades and became a symbol of women's sexual liberation. However, ruthlessly “marketed” as a sexual and hedonistic symbol, Bardot ended up succumbing to the frustration of not being taken seriously as an actress and abandoned her career to dedicate herself to campaigns for animal welfare.

item.title: Analysts highlight challenges in Macau’s economic growth
item.description: Experts contacted by the Lusa agency foresee challenges in the growth of Macau's economy for 2026, with the recovery of the gaming sector contrasting with weak domestic consumption and pressure for diversification. Economist Henry Chun Kwok Lei, professor of Business Economics at the University of Macau and vice-president of the Macau Economic Association, maintains a “cautiously optimistic” outlook for 2026, predicting Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth of around 2.5 percent during the next financial year. “The high base of gross gaming revenue this year, projected between 246 and 248 billion patacas, will condition the growth potential in 2026. Even if casino revenue increases by around 4 percent, to more than 250 billion patacas, its contribution to global economic growth will decrease,” Henry Lei told Lusa. Ben Lee, a consultant for gaming activity in Southeast Asia, has a more positive outlook. “Gross gaming revenue has already reached 226.5 billion patacas by November this year, so it is more than likely that we will exceed the projection of 228 billion,” he said. The estimate for game revenue for 2026, the analyst added, is “a little conservative”. “Unless we go back next year, based on the current situation, gross revenues could reach a value between 260 and 270 billion patacas by the end of 2026”, he estimated. Alarms sounded The forecast included in the Budget for 2025 pointed to total revenues of around 240 billion patacas, but the weak start of the year, especially after the tariff war triggered by the USA, raised alarms among the economic team of Sam Hou Fai's Executive, which approved in June an Amending Budget in which it cut 4.56 billion patacas in the revenue forecast, highly dependent on the gaming sector (around 83 percent of Macau's GDP). The Macau Economic Association predicts that annual GDP growth in 2025 will be around 5.4 percent, an estimate based on the “stable and positive trend of the main indicators of economic development, the globally stable functioning of the budgetary and financial systems and the maintenance of low unemployment rates”. As for next year, adds the association, “the Macau economy is expected to maintain a stable and positive trajectory”, although the global panorama “continues to be characterized by interconnected turbulence and complexity”. The Government Budget for 2026 points to a 3.5 percent increase in Macau casino revenues next year, reaching 236 billion patacas, still the highest value since the pandemic. Other critical challenges that Macau faces in 2026 are stimulating local consumption and supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Speaking to Lusa, Lei Choek Kuan, president of the Federation of Industry and Commerce of Macau, pointed to the “irreversible” change in consumption patterns underway and highlighted the importance of government support for companies to maintain confidence. Economist Henry Lei advocates a deeper structural transformation that goes beyond subsidies and suggested that local SMEs should look for differentiation and premium services — such as “improving after-sales service, developing creative cultural products and creating high-end culinary experiences” — to serve a niche demographic with high purchasing power, rather than competing on price with Mainland China.

item.title: CPSP | Officer drives drunk, has accident and flees the scene
item.description: The 31-year-old police officer tested the balloon and found 1.88 grams of alcohol per liter of blood. In addition to criminal liability, the CPSP initiated disciplinary proceedings against the agent An officer from the Public Security Police Corps (CPSP) is being subject to disciplinary proceedings for driving drunk, crashing his vehicle into a flowerbed and fleeing the scene. The incident happened in the early hours of December 24, when the 31-year-old man was off duty, and is therefore being investigated for the crimes of driving while drunk and evading responsibility. According to authorities, the case was detected in the early hours of December 24, when the police were called to the intersection between Rua da Barca and Rua de João de Araújo, after a vehicle crashed into a flower bed. The result was a scene of destruction that did not miss metal posts and a flowerbed. After identifying the vehicle involved in the accident, authorities approached the off-duty officer, who appeared to have a strong smell of alcohol. Suspicions that were confirmed by the balloon test, which showed a result of 1.88 grams of alcohol per liter of blood. Furthermore, the detainee's vehicle had been parked illegally. The case was forwarded to the Public Prosecutor's Office, and the agent is charged with the crimes of driving while intoxicated, which carries a sentence of up to 1 year in prison, and evading responsibility, which carries a prison sentence of up to 1 year. Alarm ringing The fact that the suspect was a CPSP agent meant that the accident merited a police reaction, via the security department's website. “The CPSP deeply regrets the case of drunk driving by a police officer, reiterating that it has always given great importance to the disciplinary behavior of its personnel” was published. The CPSP also guaranteed that the acts of agents “that violate the law and discipline are treated severely and in accordance with the law”. In addition to criminal liability, the CPSP opened a disciplinary investigation on the same day “to implement disciplinary liability in accordance with the law”. In response to the incident, it is stated on the Secretary for Security's portal that “all departments received immediate instructions to continuously reinforce the awareness and education of their subordinate officers, reminding officers that their personal conduct is linked to the positive image of the police force”. It was also highlighted that even when officers are “off duty” they must “maintain the highest standards of self-discipline and comply with laws and regulations”.

item.title: Tai Fung Bank | Fitch reduces financial viability rating
item.description: The performance of loans linked to the real estate market in Mainland China is highlighted by the rating agency as the main factor for reducing the rating to the “bb” level. The assessment on the debt issuance was maintained at “BBB+” The financial rating agency Fitch reduced Banco Tai Fung's financial viability rating from “bb+” to “bb”, warning of the possible impact of unexpected events on the institution's survival. The change was announced last week and justified by the impact of loans to the Mainland China real estate market on the bank's financial performance. The “bb” level is the fifth highest on the 10-level financial viability rating scale, but indicates the existence of “high vulnerability” in the bank’s viability, if there are “unexpected changes in long-term commercial or economic conditions”. The change in the financial viability rating comes despite Fitch recognizing that there are “moderate” expectations of the bank's continued viability and “strong financial strength”, linked to the fact that Banco Tai Fung is owned by the Bank of China. However, loans linked to the property market in Mainland China are a concern. Fitch indicates that at the end of the first half of this year, loans represented 22 percent of the bank's total assets, an exposure considered “above the banking system average of 15 percent”. “We predict that the real estate market will take time to recover, prolonging the bank’s financial recovery”, indicated the agency. In negative terms, Fitch also highlights the lower quality of the bank's assets, because the rate of non-performing loans remains “too high”, at 15.8 percent of the total of these loans. The default rate is also highlighted as a factor in the significant reduction of the bank's profits, not only due to the loans that remain unpaid, but also because the market will have a lower demand for loans, which has been one of the supports of the institution's commercial model. Support from above Despite the challenges, the bank has in its favor the fact that it is owned by the Bank of China, which analysts believe is ready to inject money into Tai Fung. The connection with the Bank of China means that the assessment on the debt issuance is maintained at “BBB+”, the fourth highest level of the 11 that constitute the rating. The Chinese state bank has a higher rating than Tai Fung in terms of debt issuance rating. Given this difference, Fitch admits an upward revision of Tai Fung's level, if there are signs that the Bank of China is ready to inject capital into the institution founded by Ho Yin. In terms of Tai Fung's operating environment, Fitch highlights that it is the fourth largest bank in Macau, measured by loan value, where gaming is expected to continue to drive economic growth.

item.title: IAM | Resident seeks compensation due to fall on bike path
item.description: After suffering injuries due to a fall on the Flor de Lótus Cycle Path, and still holding his arm across his chest, a resident asked for explanations during a session of the Board of Directors of the Institute for Municipal Affairs open to the public A local resident who suffered a fall on the Flor de Lótus Cycle Path, in Taipa, is demanding compensation from the Government, due to the existence of a hole the size of two thirds of the road. The case, reported by the newspaper Cheng Pou, happened when the resident attended the open-to-public session of the Board of Directors of the Institute for Municipal Affairs (IAM) to ask for explanations. According to the report, the citizen presented himself with an arm across his chest and stated that he had suffered several injuries on October 31, after a fall while traveling on the Flor de Lótus Cycle Path. The accident was caused by a hole that the victim claims occupied at least two-thirds of the width of the cycle path. The man suffered several bruises, dislocated a shoulder and also suffered a fractured collarbone, injuries that required him to be admitted to hospital for seven days. The resident is not satisfied with what happened and considers that there was negligence in the treatment of the cycle path by the authorities, and on November 13th he filed a claim for compensation. Furthermore, the victim attended the December meeting of the Board of Directors of the Institute for Municipal Affairs, where he made an intervention questioning the nature of the inspections. The man questioned how the IAM can claim that it carries out periodic inspections of cycle paths, at the same time that it allows the existence of such a large hole. The victim also questioned whether the hole was due to the use of inferior quality materials. The resident also pointed out that the hole was filled a month after the accident and questioned the IAM whether it only deals with infrastructure problems after there have been accidents and injuries. To follow In turn, the president of the Institute for Municipal Affairs, Chao Wai Ieng, began by wishing the resident who fell from his bicycle a speedy recovery. Regarding the questions raised, Chao Wai Ieng assured that the IAM always strives to “guarantee the suitability and safety of citizens” in the use of all public facilities. The IAM president also stated that the infrastructures are subject to regular inspections, both by the companies carrying out the works and by IAM workers. At the same time, the guarantee was made that infrastructures with more intense use, such as cycle paths, are subject to frequent and continuous maintenance. During the open session, the resident revealed that IAM is being represented by a Hong Kong office in the process relating to the compensation claim. This aspect surprised the resident, who admitted to having hung up the phone to the IAM's legal representative, during the first telephone contact, because he thought he was facing an attempted fraud.

item.title: Great Bay | Medicine internship plan with 25 places for residents
item.description: Applications are open until January 5th for the “Internship Plan for Young Doctors of Macau in the Greater Bay Area”, which will include training in traditional Chinese medicine and dentistry. The plan is based on partnerships with four hospitals in Greater Bay Area The application deadline for Macau doctors to undertake medical internships in the Greater Bay Area is now underway. The “Internship Plan for Young Doctors of Macau in the Greater Bay Area” began accepting applications on December 19th, a deadline that extends until January 5th. The plan includes 25 vacancies for Macao SAR residents with degrees in medicine, including traditional Chinese medicine and dentistry. The authorities “recently” organized a clarification session on the plan, according to a statement released yesterday by the Health Services, which was attended by more than fifty young local doctors. The internships will take place in four hospitals in the Greater Bay Area: the 1st Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University, the 5th Affiliated Hospital of the same university, the Nanfang Hospital of Southern Medical University and the Hengqin Branch of the No. 1 Affiliated Hospital of Guangzhou Medical University. According to the Health Services (SS), this measure is intended to “strengthen professional technical skills, competitiveness in the job market and expand the space for development of young doctors in Macau”. It is also intended to “support the integration [of these professionals] into the global national development strategy”. Alvis Lo, director of the SS, explained that the program “allows access to high-quality national medical training resources”, creating “a systematic and professionalized clinical training platform”. “Broadening horizons” Leong Iek Hou, director of the Center for Disease Prevention and Control, said that the plan aims to meet “the needs and gaps that exist in the training platforms for Macau doctors in Mainland China”, thus creating “a broad platform for specialized medical training”. The official stated that she hopes that health professionals can “broaden horizons, improve technical skills and professional competitiveness”. Recipients of the program are Macau residents who have a certificate of recognition of qualifications in medicine, traditional Chinese medicine or dentistry. There is no age limit, “priority is given to candidates aged 35 or younger”. Candidates can choose up to two periods of training at the same hospital, depending on “the training period and content provided by the designated medical institution”. The training lasts three, six or 12 months, “during which you will receive a monthly training allowance worth 10,000 patacas”. The list of admitted professionals will be published on January 26th.

item.title: Cinematheque Paixão | “Battle After Battle” to see on the last day of the year
item.description: Paul Thomas Anderson's new film, “Batalha Atras de Batalha”, will be shown at Cinemateca Paixão on the last day of 2025. In January, the film schedule will include Pedro Almodóvar's latest film, “The Room Next Door” and the new film by local director Tracy Choi In a dystopian scenario that, deep down, is not so different from what we live in today, there are people like Perfidia Beverly Hills, a revolutionary woman who seeks a fairer life for everyone. Perfidia maintains a relationship with another revolutionary, Bob Anderson, with whom she has a daughter, until one day everything goes wrong and Perfidia is forced to hide from everything and everyone, leaving her daughter with her father. In between, there is a soldier who will dedicate his life to persecuting this man and his daughter. Here is the synopsis of the film “Battle After Battle”, by Paul Thomas Anderson, which in almost three hours not only tells a story but also analyzes the current times in which we live, addressing topics such as immigration, social justice, racial struggles and the utopia of a better world. It is with this film that Cinemateca Paixão closes the year 2025, with a single screening on Wednesday the 31st, starting at 7:30 pm, just in time to leave the cinema and go celebrate the arrival of 2026. But the last days of the year also hold another cinematographic “cartridge”, with the screening of “Die My Love”, shown tomorrow, starting at 7:30 pm. The first day of the year brings “Flow – À Deriva”, which won the Oscar for Best Animated Film and which tells the story of a kitten who fights for survival in a world that is changing rapidly. On January 1st you can also see “A Useful Ghost”, the first feature film by Thai director Ratchapoom Boonbunchachoke, which caused a sensation at the Cannes Film Festival, winning the Critics' Week Grand Prize. This film will be shown again on the 4th, 10th and 14th of January. Almodóvar in English Cinemateca Paixão's program for January, entitled “Encantos de Janeiro”, also features the most recent film by Spanish director Pedro Almodóvar, and also his first film in English. “The Room Next Door” stars Julianne Moore and Tilda Swinton in the main roles and is a film that celebrates themes such as friendship, the meaning of life and euthanasia. The story begins when one of the women, upon learning that she suffers from a terminal illness, decides to take refuge in a house and ask a longtime friend to take care of her until the inevitable end. The public also has a session available on January 10th. On January 3rd, Cinemateca Paixão shows the documentary “Four Trails”, by director Robin Lee, which is a celebration of the nature that Hong Kong has in addition to the hustle and bustle of the city. This is the true story of Andre Blumberg, who in 2012 set himself the challenge of doing Hong Kong's four long-distance trails in just 72 hours, which translates into 298 kilometers. It is one of the most difficult marathons in the world, called the Hong Kong Four Trails Ultra Challenge. Tracy Choi's new Another major highlight of Cinemateca Paixão for the first days of the new year is the possibility of seeing the new film by local director Tracy Choi. “Girlfriends” will be shown on the 6th and 24th of January, after the film had its world premiere at the Busan International Film Festival, as part of the “Vision Asia” section. Elizabeth Tang, the film's actress, was nominated for the Best Supporting Actress award at the 62nd Golden Horse Awards, Taiwan's film awards. “Girlfriends” is about a girl who becomes a woman through three love stories set at the age of 17, 22 and 34, when she already has another maturity. It is a journey in search of love. Tracy Choi has had an acclaimed career in cinema since releasing “Sisterhood”, her first feature film.

item.title: Foreign trade | Revised law with reinforcement of responses to “external struggles”
item.description: China approved on Saturday a revision of the foreign trade law, which strengthens the legal framework for the development of cross-border trade and expands legal tools to respond to “external struggles”. According to the state agency Xinhua, the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (APN, legislative body) gave the 'green light' to the new version of the standard, which will come into force on March 1, 2026, after a vote held this Saturday. The revised law incorporates a series of reforms, which until now were applied through regulations or sectoral policies. These include the system of negative lists for cross-border trade in services, support for new formats and models of external trade, the push for digital trade and the acceleration of the construction of a “green” trade system. The text also establishes provisions for the State to advance in alignment with “high-level international economic and commercial standards” and participate in the formulation of global rules in this field, according to Xinhua. With the aim of optimizing the environment for foreign trade, the law also reinforces the protection of intellectual property rights linked to international commercial activities. In this sense, it stipulates that the State will improve the level of regulatory compliance of foreign trade operators and their ability to manage risks related to intellectual property. The standard also introduces a commercial adjustment assistance system, aimed at “stabilizing industrial and supply chains”, an aspect that has gained relevance in recent years in the face of commercial and technological frictions with the United States and other partners. In time of truce One of the highlights of the review is the expansion and improvement of the so-called “set of legal tools” for the defense of China's external interests, at a time marked by the trade truce reached with the United States and the persistence of tensions with other actors, such as the European Union. The reform is approved weeks after Beijing and Washington agreed to a one-year trade truce, which includes tariff reductions and the temporary suspension of some restrictions, although Chinese authorities have insisted, in parallel, on the need to protect national economic security.

item.title: Real Estate | Drop in birth rate linked to crisis
item.description: The president of Centaline Property Agency, Shih Wing-ching, considers that the drop in the birth rate is one of the factors that is contributing to the reduction in the value of real estate. The position was taken in an interview with am730 station, cited by Macau News Agency. According to Shih, in the last five years the price of housing in Macau has decreased by 40 percent, largely driven by the birth rate, currently 0.68 children per woman. Therefore, he appealed to the authorities to ease immigration policies, so that the price recovers again. "The continued decline has depleted residents' confidence. Even buyers are hesitant to enter the market, fearing losses in asset values," he said. The official also admitted that the Government is not exactly concerned, despite the buyers' losses: “They thought that lower house prices were not necessarily a bad thing, and that young people could thus enter the real estate market — a situation that could help with social stability, with fewer complaints”, he added.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Li Liufang (1575-1629), the painter and poet who lived for a time in retirement in his Sandalwood Garden, near the West Lake, valued affection between friends, extending to those who lived far away and even those who no longer lived but left impressive traces of their affectionate relationship with the world. Among the living, some were eminent officials and scholars who appreciated the arts such as Dong Qichang (1555-1636) but he also considered his peers to be women who clearly expressed the most subtle emotions with the brush. Among them was a former courtesan with whom he corresponded, born in Min (Fujian) but who had moved to Hangzhou near the West Lake, where she would marry and live within a traditional family. Her name was Lin Xue, also known as Lin Tiansu, and at the beginning of the 17th century, her name as a talented poet and painter would be famously mentioned by the respected Dong Qichang: «I have heard of ladies capable of painting; the first was Lin Tianxu and then Wang Youyun. Tiansu showed unrivaled beauty and Youyun, at ease in her own style.” Unlike what is usual for women who dedicate themselves to painting, she dared to create paintings of mountains and running waters (shanshui) as seen in the long, rhythmic horizontal scroll that shows a Jiangnan Scenery (ink and color on paper, 33.7 x 447.5 cm, at the National Palace Museum, in Taipei) that unfolds like a pilgrimage. His vocation and ingenuity in the art of painting can also be confirmed in works such as the boldly vertical scroll of 1621, Plum Tree and Bamboo (ink and color on paper, 86 x 18.6 cm at the Art Institute of Chicago). It contains the idea of ​​long-suffering; at the base, the bamboo that resists the forces of wind, rain and snow and, rising irresistibly, the plum tree whose flower emerges even before the end of winter. Plants grateful to literate poets and painters, such as a theme seen on a vertical scroll that echoes a tradition originating in the eleventh century. Lin Xue shows in this painting of Geese descending on the sands of the banks (ink and color on silk, 185.1 x 99.5 cm, at Smithsonian), the water birds appearing in the painted space from the upper limit of the page in an undulating and safe vertical movement until they land on the sand. The theme Pingsha luoyan, associated with the change of season «when yin increases», which is part of the memory of various arts, is mentioned in an introduction to a notation for a song in the guqin, which could be said to be an appropriate comment on Lin Xue's painting: «Against the clear autumn sky, the air is crisp and fresh while the breeze lingers calmly on the sands touched by the water. Among the clouds stretching into the distance, flying and singing, flocks of geese embody the high aspirations of those who live isolated by an excess of sensitivity.»

item.title: Carlos Morais José
item.description: Our approach to reality, no matter how disciplined and honest the approach to thought, is always ridden by error, especially when there is no alternative to the use of imagination. Geniuses, the ancient Greeks knew about the Earth's sphericity and that's why they attributed a maximum circle to the planet, which they named Ison. Today we call it Ecuador. However, these Hellene geographers considered these regions to be unreachable and uninhabitable. Torrid Zone: there, unbearable heat would boil the oceans, preventing the passage to temperate zones, postulated further south of this line that marked the maximum circle of the sphere. A simple islet, named “das Rolas”, a mere hundred meters from the island of São Tomé, in the Gulf of Guinea, is crossed by this equatorial line. This location of the former Portuguese colony provides it with a type of climate that is only found with such intensity close to the equator: the temperature varies little and, contrary to what the Greeks thought, it does not reach excessive values. Its range is between 20 and 29 degrees Celsius, but the “normal” temperature remains between 23 and 25 degrees. Night, day and throughout the year. In the permanently cloudy sky, the Sun and Moon are rarely seen. And when this happens, they never fail to appear wrapped in veils of clouds, which gives them an unreal character, invoking ancient magic, witnessing moving skies. When, towards the end of the afternoon, the rain extends its reign for more than two or three hours, often presented to plants and animals by a thunderstorm, the light dies and a very dark night reigns over the land and sea. The stars fall beyond the clouds that cover everything. On a night like this, there is no moonlight to illuminate or pierce the clouds. A deep pitch falls on the earth, a darkness that is impenetrable to our eyes. And it was like that, at three in the morning, that I woke up. My eyes opened to an abysmal darkness. Nothing, absolutely nothing could be seen. He knew he had the window open, but not a ray of light deigned to enter the room. I reached out, but the lamp didn't work. The electricity was out again. I waited for some time, hoping to get used to the blackness and discover some shapes in it. In vain. He was immersed in a well of black, warm water, he could feel the humidity on his skin, which had just woken up sweaty from a nightmare. I decided to get up and leave the house, looking for some light. The rain had stopped. Outside, the forest celebrated, hummed, reverberated with sounds. There would be millions of insects, amphibians, vertebrates, all of them nocturnal animals, also immersed in the dark, where they found food, sex and salvation. Life didn't need light. It was heard, deafening. At the edge of that spontaneous excess of trees and plants, nothing could be seen either. Dark, impenetrable dark. Only the sound prevailed, louder and louder, and suggested movements among the trees. That mixture of buzzing, squealing, buzzing, ringing, rales, loudly surrounded my ears, building a helmet that blocked all other senses, including the one that affects me in space. I was dizzy. And in that half-daziness, I groped my way back to the house, to my bed. There was nothing he could do. Forget the coffee, eliminate the possibility of reading or consulting a computer. Lying in the dark as if waking up in a coffin. Our mind cannot handle fear for long. Mostly irrational. As was the case. I can't really talk about fear, fear, but about discomfort, derived from the fragile situation that I attributed to myself. Everything could happen in that dark, and I wouldn't see him. If for some reason you had to leave the room, where would you go, if everything was plunged into darkness? But nothing was happening in the darkness of my room, nor would anything happen that would force me to grope through the pitch black, looking for a light. On the contrary, in that bed I was protected by the dark and if I saw nothing nothing would see me either. This thought provided some comfort. All things considered, that abysmal pitch was strangely comfortable for me. I made it a protective cloak and not a space of threats. And so I remained. The ancient Chinese say that everyone has an excellent place to stay. A place where you can develop and enjoy who you really are. Maybe this dark package is mine. Perhaps in it I can be for myself what I really am, setting aside what surrounds me, instructs and distracts me. I am undoubtedly alone. Without the possibility of communicating with another person or even acting in my surroundings. I'm left. With me. Alone. Isolated. Here I am not the anthropologist, nor the editor, none of my social titles perform any functions. I am not the husband, the friend or the lover. From the outside I only have the language that inhabits me and my brain rebels in search of meaning. And even this takes second place in daydreams whose material seems to emerge from another place, from knowledge not conditioned to a language — an impression of the world and not its explanation. I am a consciousness separated from things, which in the dark finds its most intimate relationship with the universe, of almost dissolution, a chamazita, a fiery being, whose interior insists on shining in the dark night. The universe and me. I'm unique. Nothing can divide me without destroying me. I know I am an individual, because I feel it deeply, with an almost painful acuity, even though neurologists tell me about the Self as an evolutionary fiction, structuralists see me as a product of Culture, psychoanalysts as a Family and Marxists as History. item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Li Liufang (1575-1629), the painter and poet who lived for a time in retirement in his Sandalwood Garden, near the West Lake, valued affection between friends, extending to those who lived far away and even those who no longer lived but left impressive traces of their affectionate relationship with the world. Among the living, some were eminent officials and scholars who appreciated the arts such as Dong Qichang (1555-1636) but he also considered his peers to be women who clearly expressed the most subtle emotions with the brush. Among them was a former courtesan with whom he corresponded, born in Min (Fujian) but who had moved to Hangzhou near the West Lake, where she would marry and live within a traditional family. Her name was Lin Xue, also known as Lin Tiansu, and at the beginning of the 17th century, her name as a talented poet and painter would be famously mentioned by the respected Dong Qichang: «I have heard of ladies capable of painting; the first was Lin Tianxu and then Wang Youyun. Tiansu showed unrivaled beauty and Youyun, at ease in her own style.” Unlike what is usual for women who dedicate themselves to painting, she dared to create paintings of mountains and running waters (shanshui) as seen in the long, rhythmic horizontal scroll that shows a Jiangnan Scenery (ink and color on paper, 33.7 x 447.5 cm, at the National Palace Museum, in Taipei) that unfolds like a pilgrimage. His vocation and ingenuity in the art of painting can also be confirmed in works such as the boldly vertical scroll of 1621, Plum Tree and Bamboo (ink and color on paper, 86 x 18.6 cm at the Art Institute of Chicago). It contains the idea of ​​long-suffering; at the base, the bamboo that resists the forces of wind, rain and snow and, rising irresistibly, the plum tree whose flower emerges even before the end of winter. Plants grateful to literate poets and painters, such as a theme seen on a vertical scroll that echoes a tradition originating in the eleventh century. Lin Xue shows in this painting of Geese descending on the sands of the banks (ink and color on silk, 185.1 x 99.5 cm, at Smithsonian), the water birds appearing in the painted space from the upper limit of the page in an undulating and safe vertical movement until they land on the sand. The theme Pingsha luoyan, associated with the change of season «when yin increases», which is part of the memory of various arts, is mentioned in an introduction to a notation for a song in the guqin, which could be said to be an appropriate comment on Lin Xue's painting: «Against the clear autumn sky, the air is crisp and fresh while the breeze lingers calmly on the sands touched by the water. Among the clouds stretching into the distance, flying and singing, flocks of geese embody the high aspirations of those who live isolated by an excess of sensitivity.»

item.title: Ana Cristina Alves
item.description:
By Ana Cristina Alves, Assistant Researcher and Coordinator of the Educational Service of the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center1 The Taoist philosophy of the beginnings, that of Laozi and the Book of Way and Virtue (《道德经/經》), will choose the water of the ocean and the sea as the privileged image of the Tao (道 Dào), that which cannot be said, without form, on which the universe itself and the ten thousand beings (万物 wânwù) that inhabit it depend, as well as the first principles of existence, the void (無/无 wú), the masculine yang (陽/阳 yáng) and the feminine yin (阴/隂yīn). This choice of an indigenous Chinese philosophy finds its echo in popular language and philosophy, for example in expressions such as “enormous capacity” (海量Hǎiliàng), which can have both an affective and social interpretation of portentous generosity or magnanimity, as well as a physical and concrete one, applying to someone who can ingest large quantities of alcohol. The sea is also linked to the word good and constant, for example in the “oath of eternal love as energetic as the sea and firm as the mountain”, where mountain lends added firmness to the promise (海誓山盟 or 山盟海誓Hǎishì-Shānméng or Shānméng-Hǎishì). The ocean, the sea, but also the great rivers are made up of generous water, both in popular and erudite Taoist philosophy. Here water is the figurative model of the Tao, as read in the Book of Way and Virtue and in the best sinology, which is why we recommend additional reading of Alan Watts Tao: The Watercourse Way. It is worth paying special attention to the chapters in which water appears as the closest representation of the Tao in the Book of Way and Virtue, namely: chapters 8, 14, 34, 66 and 78. In chapter 8 we are informed that the Tao is the supreme good “like water” (上善如水) (Abreu, 2014, 43), but it is not water itself. Therefore, it will be due to the similarity of functions that both are compared. Now water is generous, granting life to all beings, without establishing any distinction between them, its gift reaches even those that no one likes and I am thinking, for example, of parasites. It remains close to the earth to fertilize it, it is deep, simple, true, fair and correct and very timely, when it washes and cleans at the right time. This is also the case with the Tao. In the first verses of chapter XIV, regarding the Tao, an aquatic image appears again:
You look and you don't see, It's called Indistinct. You listen and you don't hear, It's called Silent. Touch and don't get caught, It's called Subtle. This trio is not decipherable For it merges into a unity 2 (Ribeiro, 2004, 32-33) And a little later we are told that he is nameless and uninterrupted (繩繩不可名) (Ibidem) The Tao is like an ocean, an uninterrupted and inexhaustible unity in which someone easily imagines themselves swimming in water that is neither too bright nor too dark, as would happen to Michael Saso in his 14th meditation on the Tao, in A Taoist Cookbook. with Meditations from the Laozi DaodeJing, which he called “Nadar no Tao” (Saso, 1994,47), a meditation that he accompanied by a recipe for spinach, soy paste and sesame, since the wise man is the one who “empties the mind and fills the belly” (虛其心實其復) (Ribeiro, 2004, 10-11), here one feels how the author is immersed in the great Tao, following with the current. Water can also be represented in a large river, as in chapter 34: The great Tao floods like a river, To the left, to the right, Ten thousand beings depend on him. （大道泛兮/其可左右/万物恃之而生） (Abreu, 2013, 94-95) In the same chapter we are told that the Tao not only gives life but nourishes and feeds, being an essential shelter in the return to the origins, not for death, but for eternal life diluted in the great unity, being therefore great, as big as the sea, or rather the great sea, which is the ocean. Whoever wants to be as it should be in existence or even correctly govern the world, must follow the model of the water in rivers and seas, as we read in chapter 66: Rivers and seas are greater than a hundred valleys Because they remain below them, and so they are princes, dominating waterfalls and streams. (江海所以能为百谷王者/以其善下之/故能为百故王)3 (Abreu,2013, 158-159) The wise man's behavior is distinguished by its malleability and spontaneity. He does not impose himself, which is why he is respected by everyone, only he should then govern, because he acts naturally, without oppressing, without hurting, letting everyone follow their course as freely as possible, as is reiterated in chapter 78: Nothing in the world is more malleable and flexible as for water, but in attacking what is hard and rigid nothing can surpass it and there is nothing to replace it. (天下莫柔弱於水/而攻堅強者莫之能先) (Ribeiro, 2004 160-161) Laozi's Taoist water is among the Five Chinese Elements (Water, Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal) the one that evokes great oceanic unity, source of life for everything that exists, but also of death, or rather, of return to origins and eternal life, when this image represents the philosophical principle Tao. And if water, fresh and salty, is the supreme good of the world, the Tao is the origin, the supreme good, including of Heaven. As a root or mysterious female (chap 6) it is the root of the cosmos as we know and experience it. He is a source of spiritual and material life, but so is water, since his model must be followed in all circumstances, from the material source of beings to complex human conduct. People who act correctly, and especially Taoist sages and saints, are aware of the physical and concrete model of water that helps them practice another invisible one, that of Tao. They will then be malleable and adaptable, capable of nourishing themselves from the inside and giving life to any form on the outside. You will know how to transform yourself to better nourish and vivify. The Taoist oceanic model differs from the one that inspired the Portuguese throughout history, who looked to the sea as their ocean. Taoist water is not challenging nor does it call for conquest, it does not have cables of storm or hope to bend, it does not require weapons or boats, nor maps, nor nautical instruments. It is the dominant, conquering element within all beings, who will adapt to this most malleable element, without needing to develop their inventive spirit. The philosophy it leads to does not ask for vigilance or a critical spirit, but adaptation to the world as it is and generosity to accept it with a minimum of suffering and a maximum of joy. item.title: UCM | White Paper suggests methods to accelerate economic diversification
item.description: The “White Paper on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”, produced at the City University of Macau, refers to inequalities in the relationship between countries and concludes that “economic diversification has advanced at a slow pace”. Bárbara Morais, main writer of the document, explains the main conclusions of the analysis A White Paper was launched on December 3rd, which provides a look and analysis of the way in which cooperation in scientific and technological areas between China, Macau and Portuguese-speaking countries has been taking place, outlining some criticisms, not only on this topic, but also on the economic direction that the Macao SAR is taking. The document, entitled “White Paper on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”, was produced by the City University of Macau (UCM) and had Bárbara Morais, a doctoral student at the institution, as main writer. In an interview with HM, she describes that, in Macau, “economic diversification has advanced at a slower pace than desired, keeping the economy structurally dependent on gambling and tourism”. "The central message of the White Paper is clear: Macau needs to accelerate the transition to functions with greater added value. However, the current context offers a renewed window of opportunity. With the support of the Greater Bay Area and, very specifically, the Deep Cooperation Zone in Hengqin, Macau now has new structural opportunities to recover lost momentum and reposition itself, not just as a cultural bridge, but as a true platform for innovation", he said. Still on the territory, but in relation to Forum Macau, the “success in institutionalizing political dialogue” is mentioned, but the White Paper “points the finger at the insufficiency of execution mechanisms”. “To streamline the role of the Forum and transform it into a tool for tangible results, the White Paper advocates a paradigm shift: it is necessary to move from declarations of intent to technicality”, describes Bárbara Morais. The doctoral student suggests “the creation of specialized technical working groups, especially in the technological sphere, and the rigorous definition of performance indicators, such as the number of registered patents, startups created or joint research projects”. “At the same time, it is suggested to establish a common agenda focused on areas of the future, such as green energy, health, the maritime economy and artificial intelligence, subject to a periodic assessment of progress”, he also said. The place of arbitration Taking these meager developments into account, the White Paper suggests that Macau assert itself “as a center for technological arbitration and intellectual property governance”. HM questioned Bárbara Morais about what should be done in effective terms, taking into account the existence, for several years, of an arbitration center, and the fact that it has been a topic on the territory's political agenda for a long time. The doctoral student highlights that “in order for these ideas, debated for years, to stop being rhetoric and become reality, the Macao SAR needs to create a legal framework specialized in technological disputes aligned with the most demanding international standards”. "It is essential to attract international experts and arbitrators through competitive incentives and establish an arbitration center that enjoys recognition both in Portuguese-speaking countries and in the Greater Bay Area. The objective is to develop mediation, certification and management services for intellectual property assets, positioning Macau as a 'safe haven', neutral and efficient, for the resolution of international technological disputes", he added. Unequal cooperation In global terms, and with regard to cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries (PLP), the White Paper refers to “top planning” by Beijing for cooperation in universities and scientific research. However, planning “does not translate, linearly, into equally effective execution mechanisms on the ground, nor does it guarantee homogeneous results among the nine Portuguese-speaking countries”. Planning implies “clear guidelines, defined priorities and diplomatic instruments mobilized to guide this cooperation”, with policies such as “Made in China 2025” or the “Digital Silk Road”, which “integrate technological cooperation with the PLP into the very core of Chinese foreign policy and national innovation”, highlights the author. However, there are “inequalities, which are perhaps the most striking feature of this relationship”, as Bárbara Morais explains. “The current scenario reveals a profound asymmetry, characterized by a ‘bicephaly’ in cooperation. (…) The main scientific capabilities, the robust technological infrastructure and the volume of effective cooperation are overwhelmingly concentrated in Portugal and Brazil”. On the contrary, “Portuguese-speaking African countries (PALOP) and Timor-Leste have a significantly lower participation”. According to Bárbara Morais, the “disparity does not arise from a lack of political will, but rather from structural funding limitations, a shortage of qualified human resources and the fragility of local research institutions”. Thus, there is “two-speed cooperation, very asymmetrical within the Portuguese-speaking community itself”. The White Paper highlights the “historic crossroads” in relation to cooperation between China and the PLP, which means “the urgent need to move from potential to implementation” in this matter. "There are ambitious visions and strategic plans, but practical results remain below what is possible. To resolve this crossroads, the proposed path involves strengthening execution mechanisms, investing massively in talent and technical-scientific education, creating ecosystems of genuine collaborative innovation between China, Macau and the PLP, and, above all, having the courage to measure results and reformulate strategies based on empirical evidence, abandoning the discourse of circumstance in favor of economic and scientific pragmatism." Gaps in Africa Another of the conclusions of the White Paper is the “tenuity” of academic links with the African continent, which Bárbara Morais describes as a “fragile scenario”. “There is a triad of factors: the scarcity of installed scientific capacity, the chronic lack of funding and consistent mobility programs”, without forgetting “the absence of stable joint research structures”. “To bridge this gap and create a lasting critical mass, the White Paper is not limited to diagnosis, suggesting concrete measures such as the robust reinforcement of research grants, the creation of joint doctoral programs, the implementation of collaborative laboratories and the design of academic mobility mechanisms specifically oriented to the African reality”, he adds. The document also talks about the negative impact of “geopolitical asymmetries”, such as the “technological restrictions of the European Union and NATO on Portugal”. According to Bárbara Morais, “real and restrictive impacts” are at stake. "These limitations condition the participation of Portugal and, by extension, of other Portuguese-speaking actors that cooperate in a network with Lisbon, in high-technology projects that involve China. The impact is particularly sensitive in critical areas such as 5G telecommunications, defense, artificial intelligence and cybersecurity, creating barriers that require complex diplomatic navigation." New strategies The White Paper was developed at the UCM Research Institute on Portuguese-Speaking Countries, and written by Bárbara Morais with the participation of academic João Simões. The project is based on a review of academic literature on the topic and also on the results of the “Technological Cooperation Launch Seminar”, held on July 22, 2025 at UCM. The work analyzes areas such as “strategic evolution”, “institutional mechanisms”, “technological milestones” and “structural challenges”, aiming to “provide evidence-based strategies to transform the potential of the China-PLP partnership into a concrete reality, creating a new model of technological cooperation for the Global South”, says a statement from UCM.

item.title: Australia | Twelve killed in attack during Jewish festival
item.description: At least twelve people died and many injured were transported to Sydney hospitals yesterday, after a shooting attack on the Australian beach of Bondi, while a Jewish celebration was taking place. “There are two people in police custody on Bondi beach”, reported the New South Wales State Police on its X account, which asks “the public to avoid the area”. Citing police sources, the AFP news agency reports that the attack caused ten deaths. The New South Wales ambulance service confirmed to ABC television that at least 16 people were transported to six hospital centers in the region. Several witnesses report that it was a shooting attack carried out by an as yet undetermined number of armed people, but the authorities have not confirmed this information either. A British tourist told French news agency AFP that he saw “two gunmen dressed in black and armed with semi-automatic rifles”. Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has already issued a statement lamenting the “shocking and distressing scenes” coming from Bondi and confirmed the existence of injuries. Part of the beach was the scene of a celebration of the Jewish festival of Hanukkah, which began yesterday and, although Australian authorities have not yet made any connection with the incident, the President of Israel, Isaac Herzog, denounced what he classified as a “vile terrorist attack against the Jews who were lighting the first candles” of the religious festival. "Our heart is with them. The heart of the entire nation of Israel beats strong at this precise moment, as we pray for the recovery of the injured, we pray for them and we pray for those who lost their lives," he said in an official statement.

item.title: Crime | Government does not release data on suicides and attempts
item.description:
After the Health Services, the Security department also stopped publishing data on suicides and attempts, after ten years of publication. The absence was noted in the release of crime data for the months of January to September this year, which show the increase in sexual abuse of minors to almost double
The Government stopped publishing data on suicide cases in Macau, as well as attempts. The absence of these numbers was noted by the newspaper Cheng Pou when it released crime data for the months of January and September this year on Friday. The publication even questions whether “the data on suicide has become ‘the secret that cannot be said’ of the authorities, committed to building a happy Macau”, remembering that this data began to be released in 2015. Highlight is the fact that the Health Services also stopped publishing the statistics, something that was done every three months. In the case of the Security Secretariat, the data was monthly and was broken down by sex, age group and methods used. The lack of numbers comes after Macau broke records in terms of suicide cases in 2024, registering 90 deaths, 2.27 percent more than in 2023. Compared to 2022, the increase was 12.5 percent. Of the 90 cases, 48 ​​concerned male victims and 42 female victims, aged between 12 and 76 years. The most recent data, for the first half of this year, reveals 41 deaths by suicide and 101 attempts. In the release of crime statistics, on Friday, only one case of death by suicide appears in relation to an episode of homicide between brothers, which occurred in August this year, in the north zone. Here, the older brother jumped from the balcony, being suspected of having killed his younger brother due to financial disputes. Break in crime Looking at the crime panorama in general terms, there is a drop of 7.1 percent in the months under analysis, compared to the same period last year. The territory's authorities highlighted the sharp drop in computer crimes. The Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, said that the drop is due to the “decreasing trend” of “crimes that attract more attention from society”, including serious violent crime, theft, robbery, fraud and computer crimes. In the first nine months of the year, 187 violent crimes were recorded, which represents a drop of 11 percent compared to the same period in 2024 (210). Thefts, robberies and frauds fell by 7.7, 5.9 and 23.6 percent, respectively. Computer crime, which recorded 770 cases in the first nine months of 2024, showed a decline of 52.1 percent in the period under analysis, with 369 cases. The decline in cases of fraud using telecommunications, cyber fraud and computer fraud, said Chan Tsz King, “reflects the effectiveness of the prevention and combat work carried out by the police, and the significant increase in public awareness about fraud prevention”, he said. The Government also highlighted that crime related to illicit gambling increased by 985 percent between January and September this year, with 394 more cases compared to the same period in 2024. The increase is due to the entry into force, in October last year, of the law to combat illicit gambling crimes, which introduced “the new crime of ‘exploitation of illicit exchange for gambling’ and expanded the scope of coverage of some crimes related to illicit gambling”. For the same reason, said the secretary, gambling-related crimes soared in the first three quarters of 2025 – 1,737 cases, 70.1 percent more than in the same period last year. In the past, the official said, fraud committed by people illegally exchanging money outside casinos “could not be identified as related to gambling”. “However, with the criminalization of ‘illegal money exchange’ and the improvement of legal provisions”, these cases “are now included in gambling crime statistics, thus increasing the number of crimes”, he indicated. More abuse of minors Chan Tsz King, who took office in October and presented the crime report for the first time on Friday, also referred to a 6.1 percent increase in crimes against the person, with child sexual abuse increasing by 86.7 percent, from 15 cases in the first nine months of 2024 to 28 cases in the same period this year. The secretary explained that these are essentially “voluntary sexual acts between people of the same age”, with “transmission of photographs and pornographic images”, without forgetting cases of “less serious sexual harassment”. “Cases involving people with family relationships were also identified, which deserves the attention of society”, said Chan Tsz King, who released data on awareness-raising actions on this problem: more than 70 activities carried out by the police, which saw the participation of more than 12,000 people, including students, guardians and teaching staff. Drug trafficking and sale and drug consumption, in turn, registered an increase of 37.1 percent, with 13 more cases, and 72.7 percent, eight more cases, respectively. According to the secretary's presentation, the 48 cases registered in the three quarters and the respective increase are due to “the discovery of several cases of cross-border drug trafficking through the reinforcement of internal and external police cooperation”, highlighting a case that occurred in September, when 31 kilos of cannabis flower worth 31.77 million patacas were seized. Chan Tsz King said that this was “the biggest case of cannabis smuggling seized in the history of Macau”. Between walls In the case of the crime of rape, there was a decline in the number of rape crimes, to a total of 24 cases, 40 percent less than in the same period of the previous year. The Secretary for Security added that “more than 70 percent of the victims were not residents of Macau”, and “the majority of these crimes occurred in hotel rooms”, while “a number of these involved pecuniary conflicts between the victims and the suspects, and it is not possible to rule out the hypothesis that some of the cases occurred in the context of a sexual transaction”. In this context, the secretary clarified that the police authorities have been “in close communication with the hotel sector”, and “police devices and inspections in peripheral areas of hotels and casinos” have been reinforced. Between January and September, more than 160 police actions were carried out to combat prostitution, with 192 people suspected of engaging in prostitution activity being intercepted. Furthermore, during the period in question, 17 cases of pimping or exploitation of prostitution were resolved, with the arrest of 26 suspects. Silence as always Questioned by Lusa during the press conference about the first case to be investigated in Macau within the scope of national security, the secretary made no comments. “The case (…) is being handled by judicial entities and, due to secrecy, it would not be appropriate for the Secretary of Security to comment”, added Chan Tsz King, who was a Public Prosecutor when former deputy Au Kam San was detained. At the end of July, the territory's police announced the arrest of Au Kam San, the first under the state security defense law, which came into force in 2009, with the scope being expanded 14 years later. The accusation is not yet known and there is no information about who will defend the former deputy. With Lusa

item.title: Economy | Deputies warn of lack of trust and inequalities
item.description: Despite economic growth throughout this year, Chan Lai Kei and Leong Sun Iok alerted the Government to the problems in community neighborhoods and the need to distribute financial resources more equitably Deputy Chan Lai Kei called on the Government to focus on promoting economic optimism and consumption, considering that in several neighborhoods in Macau the economic situation is worrying, despite macroeconomic growth. The matter was brought to the Legislative Assembly yesterday, an intervention before the agenda in the Plenary. According to the deputy linked to the Fujian community, the economy is showing a “stable recovery”. Between January and September “the initial value of GDP grew 4.2 percent compared to the same period last year”. It also indicated that the unemployment rate was 2.3 percent between August and October. However, Chan warned that “positive macroeconomic data have not completely eliminated negative indicators”, especially with regard to the lives of the population. Citing a “recent study”, the legislator indicated that there is a weak desire to consume, because “residents’ confidence in increasing income and their satisfaction with their financial situation are still between a low and medium level”. Chan Lai Kei explained that greater consumption abroad contributes to this wave of pessimism, but also the various closures of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs): “In view of the stress of consumption abroad, the business environment of SMEs in areas linked to the lives of the population (such as NAPE, Iao Hon and Fai Chi Kei) continues to worsen and the risk of closure remains”, he warned. “These companies generally face the critical challenge of unstable customer sources, high costs and cross-border consumption”, he stressed. Given the scenario outlined, the deputy asked the Executive to create a consumption incentive mechanism similar to discount vouchers, but with a permanent nature, while the “transformation phase of Macau's economic model” lasts, which “reinforces confidence in business”. Improve distribution Deputy Leong Sun Iok also addressed the situation of the economy and pointed out the need to better distribute resources from gambling, the main industry in the territory. The legislator linked to the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau praised the gaming concessionaires for the greater role they have taken in terms of investment for “urban development, tourism promotion and social security”, mainly since 2023. However, he regretted that resources are being channeled unequally: "It appears that, currently, both the revenues from the game and the gaming concessionaire companies themselves have invested a lot of resources in social development. But, in general, these resources are dispersed and lack a system and interconnection, therefore, they are unable to achieve maximum social benefit", he pointed out. Leong thus advocated that a greater proportion of the revenue collected by the Administration from gambling be channeled to the Social Security Fund, to pay pensions for the elderly. The deputy also called for the creation of a fund with money from concessionaires to develop the Macao SAR and to ensure that they “better” fulfill the obligations of the gaming law, such as “worker guarantees”, “support for people with disabilities or those rehabilitated”, support for SMEs and “educational, scientific research, environmental protection, cultural and sporting activities and activities of public interest”. Leong Sun Iok also asked for a new portal with public information on concessionaires' expenses with non-gambling activities covered by the concessions' obligations and ended the intervention with a request for caution addressed to the Executive. “Society’s resources do not come easily and are the result of the joint efforts of the Government, companies, the various social sectors and the population in general”, he indicated. "The situation is not always good. I hope the Government makes good use of the resources arising from the social responsibilities of gaming companies, to improve the lives of the population", he highlighted. Minimum Wage | Approved increase of one pataca per hour The increase of one pataca per hour in the minimum wage, from 34 to 35 patacas, was approved yesterday in the Legislative Assembly. With the changes, starting next year, in weekly terms, the salary will go from 1,632 patacas to 1,680 patacas. When the monthly calculations are made, the salary increases from 7,072 patacas to 7,280 patacas, an increase of 2.9 percent that will cover 4.4 percent of Macao SAR workers. Domestic workers are excluded, although the approval of the hiring quota, in the case of non-residents, is normally associated with the requirement of a salary between 3,500 and 4,000 patacas. Budget 2026 | Deputies approve the specialty The Legislative Assembly yesterday approved the budget for next year, which foresees an increase in gaming revenue of 3.5 percent, to 236 billion patacas. The document, which reflects the Executive's economic choices, estimates revenues of 118.8 billion patacas, while expenses are estimated at 113.5 billion patacas. Based on these perspectives, the final balance of the regular budget should be positive at 5.3 billion patacas. However, there is a possibility that the scenario is actually better, given that the Government tends to make default estimates with regard to revenue and expenses. The budget also once again provides for exemption from paying professional tax, up to 30 percent of the annual amount, limited to 144 thousand patacas.

item.title: EU | New target to reduce 90% of pollutants by 2040
item.description: MEPs and countries from the European Union (EU) yesterday reached an agreement on a target to reduce 90 percent of polluting emissions by 2040, with a view to carbon neutrality in 2050, although new forms of flexibility are foreseen. “The co-legislators agreed on a target of a 90 percent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2040, compared to 1990 levels, with the aim of achieving climate neutrality in the EU by 2050”, is announced in a statement released in Brussels. After several hours of negotiations, the European Parliament and the Council thus reached, this morning, a provisional political agreement (which will have to be confirmed by both) on an amendment to the EU Climate Law, establishing a new intermediate and binding target for 2040, that of reducing net greenhouse gas emissions by 90 percent compared to 1990 levels. Even so, MEPs and countries agreed to introduce new forms of flexibility to meet the 2040 target, “believing that the green transition and European competitiveness must advance hand in hand”, according to the note. Under review Specifically, from 2036 onwards, up to five percentage points of emissions reductions (two more than the Commission's initial proposal) could come from high-quality international carbon credits, compatible with the Paris Agreement. In the case of Portugal, for example, this means that sustainable projects in countries such as Portuguese-speaking African Countries (PALOP) can count towards the Portuguese target. “Thanks to Parliament's insistence, additional safeguards were integrated, including the prohibition of financing projects in partner countries that contradict the Union's strategic interests”, highlights the European assembly. It is up to the European Commission to analyze different options for the role of international credits in future EU climate legislation to reach the 2040 target. Furthermore, the community executive will assess progress every two years, taking into account the most recent scientific data, technological advances and the EU's international competitiveness. "The review will analyze the situation of net removals at European level, comparing it with what is necessary to meet the 2040 target, as well as possible implementation difficulties and the potential to strengthen the EU's industrial competitiveness. Trends in energy prices and their impacts on companies and families will also be considered", according to the European Parliament. This will allow Brussels to modify the 2040 target or take additional measures to strengthen the support framework, for example to protect the EU's competitiveness, prosperity and social stability. Parliament will now vote on the informal agreement and the Council will also have to approve it, with the text coming into force 20 days after its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union. The European Climate Law makes each country's effort to reduce its polluting emissions legally binding.

item.title: Europe | Merz considers aspects of Trump's geostrategy unacceptable
item.description: The head of the German federal government, Friedrich Merz, declared yesterday that there are certain unacceptable points in the document on Defense and geostrategy of the North American Administration led by Donald Trump, from a European perspective. “I don’t see any need for Americans to want to save Democracy in Europe,” he said, on a visit to Rhineland-Palatinate (a southwestern state), which is home to several United States of America (USA) military bases. In a strategic document on US national security, released last week, there is a warning about the danger of “civilizational extinction” in Europe if “current trends” continue. Trump, in the preface, summarizes: “we put America first in everything we do”. “It is more than plausible that, in a few decades at most, the members of NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organization) will become predominantly non-European”, he wrote, adding that “it is legitimate to question whether they will perceive their place in the World or their alliance with the USA, in the same way as those who signed the organization's charter”. The White House regrets European decisions that “undermine political freedom and sovereignty, the migration policies that are transforming the continent [Europe] and creating tensions, as well as the censorship of freedom of expression and the repression of political opposition, the drop in birth rates and the loss of national identities (…)”. Washington expresses the desire for “Europe to remain European, regain its civilizational self-confidence and abandon its fruitless obsession with regulatory suffocation.”

item.title: East Timor | Memories of a man's life reflect the resistance of a people
item.description: The book “Return to Uaidora, the childhood and youth of Domingos Gusmão” recounts the Timorese's testimonies about the years of Timor-Leste's resistance to the Indonesian occupation. The testimony was written in Macau by former resident and university professor Duarte Trigueiros. 50 years after the occupation, the author reminded HM of the work launched in 2022 This year has been marked by the celebrations of the 50th anniversary of the independence of many former Portuguese colonies. Timor-Leste went to one of these territories. However, shortly after the unilateral proclamation of independence, on November 28, 1975, there was a period of confrontation that culminated in the Indonesian occupation, on December 7 of the same year. This Sunday marks 50 years since the invasion that marked the fate of the young country. In connection with this date, the book “Regresso a Uaidora, the childhood and youth of Domingos Gusmão” was released in 2022, which reveals the story of the Timorese, who was a student in Macau and a student of the author Duarte Trigueiros, former economist and professor at the University of São José. HM spoke to the author about the reflection of the pain and struggle for self-determination of a people that can be seen in the life of a man and his family. "When I was teaching in Macau, I collected the testimony of this Timorese from Baucau. Domingos Gusmão, knowing that he had taught at the National University of Timor-Leste for several years, told me how he and his family lived through all these terrible events." This is how the book was born, with Trigueiros merely reporting the testimony, later corrected in partnership with Domingos Gusmão. The work only has an online version, but at the time of launch it had the support of Fundação Oriente in printing some copies. Matebian, East Timor Duarte Trigueiros, who lived in Macau for several years, came into contact with Domingos Gusmão during the Festa da Lusofonia, in 2015. "I went to the Timor-Leste tent and he told me that he had interesting things to tell me, but that he couldn't speak Portuguese well, and that he would like to leave his testimony in writing. At one point I proposed asking him questions from his childhood, about life in the village, and thus the book was born, with nine chapters.” The beginning of the work describes, “through the eyes of a child, the day-to-day life of farmers in the Baucau mountains in Timor-Leste, the determination in which they reacted to the invasion of their country in 1975 and the brutal repression that followed”. "The book follows not only his life, but also his family and the few who remained. In the end, there was practically no one left", describes Duarte Trigueiros. According to the work, Domingos Gusmão was born on November 1, 1969 in the village of Uaidora, belonging to the municipality of Baucau, the son of Julião, a farmer, and Juliana, a maid. "But only the place where I was born is correct. The date of birth is nothing more than a conjecture and the names that appear on the certificate as being my parents, Julião and Juliana, are also not those of my real father and mother, but of relatives who adopted me when I was an orphan. In fact, I am the son of Martinho Gusmão, whose code name was 'Maunoco' and he was the chief of the Uaidora village until his death in 1983; and my mother was Ricardina, Martinho Gusmão’s second wife, the one who gave him offspring.” This is how Domingos’ story begins. Going to Baucau The work recounts very difficult years, with thousands of Timorese fleeing into the bush to escape the Indonesians, organizing armed struggle. One of the chapters, highlights Duarte Trigueiros, reports how Domingos and his family "were deported and left without any type of support, without doctors or food. "A huge number of people died at that time, until the beginning of the 80s, and they [Dominicos Gusmão's family], already in the place where they were cultivating the land, began to have fruits from the land, and send children to school. This boy [Domingos Gusmão], during that time, started preparing to go to Baucau to study, something that was not easy, as it was necessary to find a place, and there were many children.” Domingos and Xanana Gusmão It was there that the family decided to leave the village and go to Baucau, finding jobs “at the service of the troops, judges, nurses and doctors”, which gave them their first contacts with the Timorese resistance. "He [Domingos Gusmão] began organizing what they called a clandestine front with his colleagues. The book reports all these adventures that clearly reveal how the resistance worked. This boy then felt the desire to continue his studies and applied to a Catholic seminary", recalled Duarte Trigueiros. The connection to the Catholic religion was not an accident. "The purpose was to go abroad, because the only thing that Indonesians really respected was the Catholic Church, they didn't respect anything else. And he left, spent a number of years training. He was in the Philippines, where he also participated in resistance activities, and returned as a priest, in 2012." Writing this book was important to Domingos Gusmão because he “wanted to mention the names of the [Timorese] commanders of the first phase, when the Indonesian troops entered through Baucau, towards the interior, and there were a large number of resistance commanders who resisted, almost without weapons, and were killed”. “When he spoke to me about this subject, he was very insistent, he told me ‘Write down the name of that commander.’ Everything so that the names would not be forgotten”, he recalled.
