"What he told me is that nowadays, in Timor-Leste, people are compensating the members of the resistance who are alive, but there are many dead who gave their lives for this and are being forgotten. But this book also talks about everything on a personal level, about what happened to the uncle, how the father died at that stage, thrown to the ground, with a gun butt, with kicks, because he refused to accept an order and they threw him to the ground. He was the head of the village and had to accept the order [of the Indonesians], but he refused”, highlighted Duarte Trigueiros. For the author, the work tells “a truer version” of what the Indonesian occupation was, and very specifically about the experiences of the town of Uaidora and the interior of the country. In the book, you can read Domingos' testimony about this phase of resistance in Baucau, starting in 1986. “I owe my enlistment in the resistance to the clandestine fronts and also to my colleague Domingos de Oliveira. (…) A few weeks later, on the 16th or 17th of September 1991, the centenary of the Dili cathedral was celebrated and young people were invited to participate. 14 left from Baucau. Buses full of teenagers and I was one of them. The next day, during the return trip, FRETILIN flags appeared and we all sang hymns to independence. As we passed through Manatuto, the troops ordered us to stop, but then they told us to continue; and at the entrance to Baucau, before the airport, the road was blocked and we were surrounded by a strong military device. There were only three assault cars!” Gusmão continues his account of this tense moment. "After having cornered us like this, the troops, with the assault vehicles on the right side, occupied the left side. The 14 trucks were lined up with the military device, which had its weapons in position, ready to fire. They were like a very long firing squad. There we stayed, with all those weapons pointed at us, in silence while time passed and nothing happened." Support from Portuguese Duarte Trigueiros and Domingos Gusmão kept in touch, but a stroke took away the Timorese's quality of life. "He hardly responds to my emails. Maybe he has a different outlook on life", confesses the author. Another perspective that the work gives, according to Trigueiros, is the position of the Portuguese authorities during the years of Indonesian occupation, dispelling the idea that there was abandonment after independence. "I simply show what Domingos told me, and he told me that many of the resistance commanders had been Portuguese soldiers and that, therefore, they knew how to use weapons. He also told me that they were extremely patriotic. There is a report that in the 90s they tried to get a satellite phone from Portugal to give to the resistance, and there are references to the support of the Portuguese Embassy in Manila. I think we looked good in the photograph", he concludes. Duarte Trigueiros taught in Timor between 2004 and 2009, where he found higher education very weak. "The students practically didn't know Portuguese and we had to teach in Portuguese. That alone was a huge effort. In general, the students were weak, they were very poorly prepared. The [educational] preparation of the Indonesians had been of a low level, as there was discrimination against students for being Timorese. The book describes this, how only good students had the right to move up, so to speak, and that didn't even mean going to university." Even so, Duarte Trigueiros highlights the training of “a good number of people, engineers, law graduates, economists”. “It took a lot of work and that was the great support that Portugal was able to give”, he added. Today, the former economist says that the Timorese look at the Portuguese with immense gratitude. "It's amazing, because when we go on a street with an Australian, they despise the Australian and don't talk to him, but with the Portuguese they shower him with all kinds of affection. This happens a lot in Timor-Leste", he concluded.

item.title: IAM | Resident seeks compensation due to fall on bike path
item.description: After suffering injuries due to a fall on the Flor de Lótus Cycle Path, and still holding his arm across his chest, a resident asked for explanations during a session of the Board of Directors of the Institute for Municipal Affairs open to the public A local resident who suffered a fall on the Flor de Lótus Cycle Path, in Taipa, is demanding compensation from the Government, due to the existence of a hole the size of two thirds of the road. The case, reported by the newspaper Cheng Pou, happened when the resident attended the open-to-public session of the Board of Directors of the Institute for Municipal Affairs (IAM) to ask for explanations. According to the report, the citizen presented himself with an arm across his chest and stated that he had suffered several injuries on October 31, after a fall while traveling on the Flor de Lótus Cycle Path. The accident was caused by a hole that the victim claims occupied at least two-thirds of the width of the cycle path. The man suffered several bruises, dislocated a shoulder and also suffered a fractured collarbone, injuries that required him to be admitted to hospital for seven days. The resident is not satisfied with what happened and considers that there was negligence in the treatment of the cycle path by the authorities, and on November 13th he filed a claim for compensation. Furthermore, the victim attended the December meeting of the Board of Directors of the Institute for Municipal Affairs, where he made an intervention questioning the nature of the inspections. The man questioned how the IAM can claim that it carries out periodic inspections of cycle paths, at the same time that it allows the existence of such a large hole. The victim also questioned whether the hole was due to the use of inferior quality materials. The resident also pointed out that the hole was filled a month after the accident and questioned the IAM whether it only deals with infrastructure problems after there have been accidents and injuries. To follow In turn, the president of the Institute for Municipal Affairs, Chao Wai Ieng, began by wishing the resident who fell from his bicycle a speedy recovery. Regarding the questions raised, Chao Wai Ieng assured that the IAM always strives to “guarantee the suitability and safety of citizens” in the use of all public facilities. The IAM president also stated that the infrastructures are subject to regular inspections, both by the companies carrying out the works and by IAM workers. At the same time, the guarantee was made that infrastructures with more intense use, such as cycle paths, are subject to frequent and continuous maintenance. During the open session, the resident revealed that IAM is being represented by a Hong Kong office in the process relating to the compensation claim. This aspect surprised the resident, who admitted to having hung up the phone to the IAM's legal representative, during the first telephone contact, because he thought he was facing an attempted fraud.

item.title: DSAMA | Authorities prepare for dry period
item.description: Local and Zhuhai authorities met on the 19th to discuss preventive water storage to combat saline intrusion, which will lead to a dry period until February. The meeting was held between the Bureau of Maritime and Water Affairs (DSAMA), the Zhuhai Water Affairs Bureau and Zhuhai Water Environment Holdings Group LTD. Taking into account the forecasts of water authorities in Mainland China, “the natural inflow to the Xi River basin is expected to be between 10 and 30 percent below the average between December 2025 and February 2026, indicating drier conditions than usual this winter and next spring”, is mentioned in the DSAMA statement. Taking this scenario into account, it was indicated that, currently, “effective storage capacity has reached 90 percent, exceeding the levels observed in the same period of previous years”, and “all reservoirs in Zhuhai are operating with high water levels”, with their maintenance completed before the arrival of this “dry period”. Susana Wong, director of DSAMA, said that “over the years, the Zhuhai Water Affairs Department has continuously strengthened its capacity to guarantee the supply of raw water to Macau”. The official also said, regarding the emergency water supply capacity in Macau, that “the project to expand the Seac Pai Van Reservoir is ongoing and its completion is scheduled for 2028”, and “after completion, Macau's water consumption autonomy will increase to 12 days”. The meeting also served to discuss the price of raw water for the years 2026 to 2028, taking into account that “the Guangdong-Macao Water Supply Agreement provides for a three-yearly adjustment of the price of raw water supplied by Zhuhai to Macau, with 2026 being the next year of adjustment”.

item.title: Great Bay | Medicine internship plan with 25 places for residents
item.description: Applications are open until January 5th for the “Internship Plan for Young Doctors of Macau in the Greater Bay Area”, which will include training in traditional Chinese medicine and dentistry. The plan is based on partnerships with four hospitals in Greater Bay Area The application deadline for Macau doctors to undertake medical internships in the Greater Bay Area is now underway. The “Internship Plan for Young Doctors of Macau in the Greater Bay Area” began accepting applications on December 19th, a deadline that extends until January 5th. The plan includes 25 vacancies for Macao SAR residents with degrees in medicine, including traditional Chinese medicine and dentistry. The authorities “recently” organized a clarification session on the plan, according to a statement released yesterday by the Health Services, which was attended by more than fifty young local doctors. The internships will take place in four hospitals in the Greater Bay Area: the 1st Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University, the 5th Affiliated Hospital of the same university, the Nanfang Hospital of Southern Medical University and the Hengqin Branch of the No. 1 Affiliated Hospital of Guangzhou Medical University. According to the Health Services (SS), this measure is intended to “strengthen professional technical skills, competitiveness in the job market and expand the space for development of young doctors in Macau”. It is also intended to “support the integration [of these professionals] into the global national development strategy”. Alvis Lo, director of the SS, explained that the program “allows access to high-quality national medical training resources”, creating “a systematic and professionalized clinical training platform”. “Broadening horizons” Leong Iek Hou, director of the Center for Disease Prevention and Control, said that the plan aims to meet “the needs and gaps that exist in the training platforms for Macau doctors in Mainland China”, thus creating “a broad platform for specialized medical training”. The official stated that she hopes that health professionals can “broaden horizons, improve technical skills and professional competitiveness”. Recipients of the program are Macau residents who have a certificate of recognition of qualifications in medicine, traditional Chinese medicine or dentistry. There is no age limit, “priority is given to candidates aged 35 or younger”. Candidates can choose up to two periods of training at the same hospital, depending on “the training period and content provided by the designated medical institution”. The training lasts three, six or 12 months, “during which you will receive a monthly training allowance worth 10,000 patacas”. The list of admitted professionals will be published on January 26th.

item.title: CCAC | Investigation into special taxis confirmed
item.description: Commissioner Against Corruption, Ao Ieong Seong, assured yesterday that an investigation into the supervision of the special taxi service is underway, but declined to comment specifically on whether the former director of the Traffic Affairs Service Bureau, Lam Hin San, is being targeted. Speaking on the sidelines of the sovereignty transfer ceremonies, Ao Ieong Seong stated that the investigation is administrative in nature, and seeks to determine whether there was any type of violation of administrative processes in supervising the service. In June this year, an investigation by the Audit Commission identified several irregularities in the inspection process, which meant that the number of special taxis in circulation never reached the numbers predicted and promised in the public tender. As a result of these failures, it is practically impossible to book a taxi in advance by phone. Ao Ieong Seong also stated that he is aware of some opinions that there may have been “negligence” by the services in the inspection, but he refused to draw any conclusions before completing the investigation. The director of the Commissariat Against Corruption (CCAC) also addressed the situation of Creche Smart, which has a dispute in court against the Institute of Social Action (IAS). In March, it was announced that the daycare center managed by the Zona Club de Macau association would see its funding cut by the IAS and that it would have to hand over the facilities where it currently operates. However, the daycare management always challenged the IAS measures and took the case to court. Ao Ieong Seong stated yesterday that an investigation is underway into the IAS' procedures regarding the daycare center and acknowledged that there is also a case in the courts. However, Ao Ieong Seong promised that the CCAC's findings will not impact the courts' final decision because they are independent investigations. The CCAC director also indicated that she had received various information from the daycare center in more recent times.

item.title: Celebration | Sam Hou Fai says Macau “is more vibrant than ever”
item.description: In his reception speech for the celebration of the 26th anniversary of the establishment of the MSAR, the Chief Executive optimistically praised the moment Macau is going through. “The great practice of the ‘One Country, Two Systems’ principle has achieved enormous successes in this promising land that is Macau, this ‘pearl in the palm of the Fatherland’, ‘precious land of the Fatherland’ that gains shine day after day, is more vibrant than ever and opening a phase of development unparalleled in its history”. Sam Hou Fai's optimistic tone continued, entering into one of the main objectives of successive Macau governments, the economic diversification of the territory, remembering that Xi Jinping “urged Macau to fly higher and go further to achieve greater successes”. The official added that the Chinese President's instructions “are of great significance”, encouraging “to continue the fight with commitment to take a new leap and to create new splendid successes”. Sam Hou Fai continued, highlighting that Macau is at its best moment of development. Regarding the closure of the satellite casinos, in the press conference that followed, the leader of the Executive reiterated that it is taking place in an orderly manner, and that the approximately 3,500 workers involved have their jobs secured. Furthermore, he added that so far there is no record of complaints filed by workers.

item.title: Government | Reinforcing patriotism, security and connection to Lusophony are priorities
item.description: Reinforcing “love for the Fatherland”, national security legislation and links with Portuguese and Spanish speaking countries were priorities outlined yesterday by the Chief Executive on the 26th anniversary of the Macao SAR “We must (…) comprehensively implement the principle of ‘Macau governed by patriots’, to strengthen the foundations of love for the country and for Macau”, said the leader of the Government, Sam Hou Fai, yesterday morning, in a speech in which he mentioned the name of President Xi Jinping nine times, with whom he met this week in Beijing. The discourse on reinforcing patriotism and love for the country has intensified in recent years in Macau and is present in practically all sectors of society. Also in the local legislative body, as Sam Hou Fai highlighted yesterday. “The election work for the 8th term of the Legislative Assembly was successfully concluded with the effective implementation of the principle of ‘Macau governed by patriots'”, he declared. In July, the State Security Defense Commission – whose inherent president is Sam Hou Fai – excluded all 12 candidates from two lists competing for the AL, considering them “not defenders of the Basic Law or not faithful” to the Macau Special Administrative Region (SAR). One of them was the list of former deputy Ron Lam U Tou, one of the most critical voices of the Government in the Legislative Assembly. National security also received attention from Sam Hou Fai, who was sworn in exactly one year ago in Macau by Xi Jinping. Sam once again highlighted, as he had already done during the presentation of the Government program for 2026, that he will reinforce legislation for national security. "Security constitutes the condition of development, just as development ensures security. We must consolidate the firm barrier in favor of safeguarding the country's sovereignty, security and development interests, improve the legal regime for the defense of national security and the respective execution mechanism", he indicated. Iberian horizon Sam mentioned this week, for the first time, the detention, at the end of July, of former pro-democracy deputy and Portuguese citizen Au Kam San, the first under the Defense of State Security Law, which came into force in 2009 and was extended in 2023. “We detained a former member of the Legislative Assembly for endangering national security”, said the person in charge on Wednesday. Yesterday's stage was also destined for Lusophony and for the new player in a possible triangular relationship with China: the universe of Spanish-speaking countries. “We will continually expand our international network of partners, acting appropriately as a ‘precision interlocutor’ between China and Portuguese and Spanish-speaking countries, transforming Macau into a higher level platform for openness to the outside world”, he promised. China established the Macau Special Administrative Region (SAR) as a platform for strengthening economic and trade cooperation with Portuguese-speaking countries in 2003. More than two decades later, the Macau Government expanded the focus to Spanish-speaking countries. Cooperation must focus, as Sam indicated in November in the general presentation of the Government program, on, among other sectors, the areas of finance, culture, tourism and cross-border electronic commerce. “Thus, Macau, as a bridge between East and West, will be able to shine with renewed splendor in the new era and contribute to the country’s high-quality opening to the outside world”, he stated in yesterday’s speech. The long-standing goal of the territory's successive governments, the diversification of Macau's economy, which is deeply dependent on the gaming sector, continues to be a priority of the Executive leader, who promised to “persistently concentrate efforts on overcoming obstacles”. In this sense, he promised, among other actions, to “pragmatically accelerate the construction of the Cooperation Zone”, referring to the Deep Cooperation Zone between Guangdong and Macau, created in Hengqin in 2021, with around 106 square kilometers, to support Macau's economic diversification and integration into the rest of China.

item.title: Sam Hou Fai's first year was proactive in diversifying the economy
item.description: Analysts told Lusa that the Chief Executive's first year in office was marked by the desire to lead the diversification of the Macao SAR's economy, which is highly dependent on casinos. Sam Hou Fai, who took office exactly one year ago, “adopted a proactive approach to leading the process of economic diversification”, argued Henry Lei Chun Kwok. The professor at the University of Macau gave as an example the creation of two funds, one to support industries and the other for scientific and technological research, and the creation of a science and technology park. Something that “differs from the previous market-oriented approach, and which is crucial given the uncertainties and weak investor confidence we currently face”, highlighted the specialist in business economics. The president of the Luso-Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry stressed that Sam Hou Fai “did not start from scratch” and that economic diversification was already a Macau policy “in the medium and long term”. "There is, let's say, a train moving and that train continues. You can increase the speed slightly, or reduce the speed, but the path was more or less traced", said Carlos Cid Álvares. The difference, explained deputy Leong Hong Sai, is that “in the past, the importance of achieving economic and industrial diversification was discussed for many years”. “Now, this is actually being implemented, with general planning and site selection taking place in an orderly manner”, highlighted the vice-president of the General Union of Residents’ Associations of Macau. Even so, Henry Lei warned that “it may take some time for efforts to produce measurable progress, such as an increase in added value or the share of the technology sector in GDP [Gross Domestic Product]”. Cid Álvares also sees projects that are “interesting and can move the economy”: a cultural zone, under public consultation until December 26th, and the university city in Hengqin. Iberian tour Cid Álvares, also executive director of Banco Nacional Ultramarino – part of the Caixa Geral de Depósitos group – believes that the visit that Sam Hou Fai plans to make to Portugal and Spain could help attract companies and investment. “I believe this could make more eyes turn here, because, for me, Macau is not 600 thousand inhabitants, it is 80 million in the Greater Bay Area, with 12 percent of China's GDP”, argued Cid Álvares. The president of the CCILC says that “there is already greater attention to Hengqin” and predicted that, “in the long term, the borders will be greatly simplified and, therefore, Macau and Hengqin will be more integrated”. There have been “significant efforts” towards greater integration of Macau, namely “the convergence of legal rules”, but Leong Hong Sai argued that “progress must be accelerated”. Henry Lei, on the other hand, highlighted the priority of “overcoming inefficiency in the mobility of resources, such as capital and information flows, to reinforce integration between Macau and Hengqin [and] attract more cross-border investment”.

item.title: It’s good for Ukraine
item.description: I do not discuss the past or the personality of Vladimir Putin. I do not discuss Russia's expansionist policy. I discuss the politics of Portugal and the European Union. In Portugal there are around four million citizens who live on the edge of poverty. There are thousands of Portuguese people with poor pensions. There are elderly people living alone without any medical or social support. There are homes that are human rubbish bins. There are not enough public daycare centers for Portuguese children. There are hundreds of slums. There are hundreds of homeless people, cold and hungry, all over the cities. There are buildings owned by the Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Lisboa, with more than five floors, completely abandoned and in ruins in a country where there is no social housing for young people, the elderly, the disabled and families who survive by having to choose whether to purchase food or medicine. There are young people who, at the age of 40, still live in their parents' homes because they are unable to rent or buy a house, much less live in a civil union with a partner and have children. There is a Ministry of Defense that announces the future purchase of war material and aircraft worth billions of euros when public hospitals have closed emergency rooms and future mothers are giving birth at home, in ambulances, in private cars or on the street. There are blind and disabled people who cannot use certain Lisbon Metro stations because there are no elevators or escalators. There are prison establishments where inmates are provided with a type of food that even dogs reject. There are students who finish secondary school and go to work in a restaurant or in the construction industry because their parents do not have money to pay for tuition fees and university supplies. There are beggars asking for money every day in every city in the country. There are more than 100,000 poor people who have been suspended from a miserable monthly income subsidy of 200 euros. There are poor people stealing chocolate or bread from a supermarket and are immediately taken to a police station. There are no safe institutes that care for women who are victims of domestic violence. There are political parties that advocate the expulsion from Portugal of immigrants who work and contribute to Social Security. There is an annual increase for retirees of three to five euros. Politics in Portugal, undeniably, despises the poor, with the argument that the State Budget is not enough for more. And, after all, what happens? That the Portuguese Government has sent billions of euros to Ukraine. For a country, whose Parliament has a majority of neo-Nazis. A country that has corrupt ministers and head of presidential cabinet at the highest level. A country where President Zelensky has fired minister after minister for embezzling millions of dollars from the European Union and obviously from Portugal. A country where the people are divided between general elections, even in times of war. A country that six years ago was “exporting” to Portugal one of the largest mafias dedicated to human trafficking, serious robberies of value vans, control of prostitution of Ukrainian women disguised as domestic workers, drug sales and money laundering. Portugal continues to send millions of euros to Ukraine, when its people live in poverty and misery. A policy of this kind is not acceptable, where people are already afraid to speak out against decisions related to financial support for Ukraine, because they could run the risk of being accused of supporting the communist Putin. It is not acceptable that the policy of North American interests, led by its president Donald Trump, which supports the most diverse neo-Nazi organizations, including Ukrainian ones, leads Portugal to send millions of euros, who knows what destination, and keeping thousands of its children in poverty. It is urgent and minimally reasonable that the Portuguese government immediately cease sending millions of euros and war material or aircraft to Ukraine, when this money is so desperately needed by the poor residents of the seaside country. Human solidarity is not this. The Ukrainian people have benefited nothing from the millions from Portugal and other European countries. We have reached the point where military material is being sent to Ukraine and many Ukrainian government officials are selling that same material to Afghanistan and other countries like that. Readers must take a position, within each individual's possibilities, to make the Portuguese authorities aware that the situation described here cannot continue. For the good of the Nation.

item.title: Policies for attracting investment, valuation services and inspection of the Science and Technology Park
item.description: The Science and Technology Park is linked to the future of Macau Deputies Lei Wun Kong and Wong Ka Lon Macau's economy is overly dependent on gaming revenue, but with the emergence of artificial intelligence in the industry, young people are no longer enthusiastic about offline gaming. With the passage of time, changes in the external situation and other factors, gaming revenues may be unstable and affected. Therefore, the Science and Technology Park project is the key to adequate diversification of the economy. Question: Create and improve policies for attracting investment and post-investment services and supervision of the aforementioned Park Nowadays, businesspeople are more conservative. To efficiently promote the Park project in question, the Government must take the initiative to attract investments and provide enhancement services. Despite the efforts made by public services, namely the Secretariat for Economy and Finance and its subordinate services, it is necessary to create and improve policies for attracting investment, post-investment services and supervision of the aforementioned Park. Model: Taking the experiences of model cities in Mainland China as a reference In recent years, model cities in Mainland China have defined five models for attracting investment. The first is through capital, “funds + industries”, the government creates an industrial fund to promote the implementation of projects, such as the Suzhou biotechnology industry. The second is through a cluster “led by dominant industries”, that is, creating an industrial cluster around dominant companies, for example, in Shenzhen it is Huawei that drives the respective industries. The third is based on “demand-driven supply”, that is, exploring application scenarios to attract technology companies, for example, the company Hangzhou City Brain integrated Alibaba Cloud to develop the application of AI. The fourth is based on “intelligent data matching” to capture digital investments, that is, the creation of big-data to accurately define target companies, such as the “digital investment capture” system in Guangzhou. The fifth is based on “interregional cooperation”, that is, it transcends the delimitation of administrative regions, such as the Shenzhen-Shantou cooperation zone, led by Shenzhen. Strategy: Develop differentiated policies according to the reality of Macau Macau, as a micro-economy, in addition to the lack of human resources and land, does not have dominant companies, so it is difficult to create an industrial cluster. Therefore, we must maximize our unique advantages (such as the “one country, two systems” principle, free port, autonomous customs zone, simple tax regime, connection platform with Portuguese-speaking countries and the European legal system, and transform all of this into concrete and attractive points and services for attracting investment), and transform Macau into a platform for interconnection between scientific and technological companies from China and the PLP. Therefore, we can take the following measures: 1) based on the performance agreement, promote industrial orientation through strategic social participation of the industrial fund, in order to achieve the leverage effect of capital with controlled risk; 2) promote cooperation in attracting inter-regional investment, clearly define the division of labor with Henqin and ensure investment effectiveness; 3) capture local and international talent to attract investments, granting qualified candidates non-permanent resident status; 4) create a large bank to attract investments, etc. At this time, it is necessary for the Government to implement policies to attract investment through legal incentives aimed at businesspeople who want to enter the park. The investment capture model, operational management and preferential policies, among other key steps, must be clarified. The capture of high-level investments must be ensured and the management process detailed a posteriori, in order to highlight the change in the role of the Government, from manager to service provider, achieving the articulation of these measures with the 15th Five-Year Plan of the Country and the needs and advantages of Macau. Guarantee: Improvement of value-added services and quantitative supervision When attracting investments, star cities in Mainland China, in addition to providing value-added services to companies for investment, should facilitate the development of these companies, guiding them towards their continuous growth. Once the process of attracting investments is completed, the phase of monitoring the production value and investment intensity per acre of land follows, which will be used as a basis for determining the value of subsidies and benefits granted by the respective governments. Although it is difficult for Macau to adopt the quantification model per acre of land, it can carry out an appropriate quantification, taking into account its own needs. For example, taking as quantitative indicators the intensity of employment, the size of investment and possible entry into the capital market. Thus, these values ​​determine the financial support that is granted, as well as tax benefits and other incentive measures. At the same time, as the area of ​​the scientific and technological park and human resources are limited, it is necessary to better define the proportion of each sector, but the blind search for a “large and complete” scope must be avoided. Furthermore, policies should be oriented towards Hengqin-Macao cooperation, cooperation inside and outside the park, and industry-academia-research purposes. In short, the Government must create an improved system of value-added services and quantitative supervision for attracting investments, in order to achieve advances in several dimensions, namely in “industrial positioning, excellent complementary policies, deep synergy between Macau and Hengqin, the ecosphere of the investment capture process, and the management of business confidence”.

item.title: Is erotic audio storytelling replacing video?
item.description: Eroticism is gaining a new voice — literally. While video dominated the mainstream sexual imagination for decades, today audio narrative sexual fantasy is experiencing a moment of great popularity: erotic podcasts, apps that tell sensual stories and audiobooks capable of provoking arousal. It is a form of eroticism that appeals to imagination, intimacy and personal experience in a way that visual pornography rarely does. The audio format works in a radically different way than video. When we watch videos, we receive a ready-made image, a visual script that dictates what should excite us. They are bodies with specific characteristics, many of them with surgical alterations that follow fashions of what is supposed to be sensual or exciting. The audio, on the other hand, works as a suggestion: we are the ones who build the setting, the characters and the chemistry. The narrative comes into play as a kind of trigger — a trigger that allows the imagination to do what it does best: create our own erotic fantasy. When we listen to an erotic audio story, our brains are not just processing external stimuli; they are actively collaborating with the narrative, filling spaces, generating unique images and sensations. This participation can heighten the erotic response in a way that is different from the more passive experience of watching a screen. These audio stories manage to center the experience on the listener, often placing them in the main role of the fantasy and creating a sense of connection and intimacy that is difficult to replicate on video. The growing popularity of audio erotica appears to respond to emotional and sexual needs that many people feel are not addressed by traditional forms of pornography. With the narrative, the listener stops being just a consumer and becomes involved in a process of co-creation of the erotic. Apps like Quinn or Dipsea produce narrated stories, often focused on the listener's perspective — with voices, ambient sound and an engaging narrative — rather than explicit images. It is not only the nature of eroticism that explains this growing popularity, but also the audience for whom these stories are created. Many of these apps and podcasts are designed by women and for women, or for queer people. Pornography, historically associated with the male gaze and desire (with some exceptions), tends to leave out other equally relevant imaginaries. Erotic audio narratives have explored precisely those territories traditionally considered more “feminine”: consent, emotion, vulnerability and female pleasure. Here, the focus on history and anticipation builds a form of eroticism that privileges connection — without ever giving up on excitement. The success of these apps, podcasts and audio stories suggests that many people are looking for stories that include them and respect their rhythms and desires, especially those who have never recognized themselves in mainstream erotica. The focus on emotional connection, the simple fact that someone whispers sensual words directly into the headphones, creates an intimate and almost confidential experience. This emotional rarity — feeling heard, desired and imagined in the erotic universe — makes audio simultaneously exciting, liberating and safe. The return to voice can, therefore, be more than a passing fad. It may be a reflection of how we want to experience eroticism today: not as distant spectators, but as active participants in our own erotic co-creation.

item.title: Lessons from 2025 for the Decade
item.description: (Continuation of the article published on December 11) In the security sector, the world will face complex challenges. Terrorism could take on new forms, using digital technologies and artificial intelligence. Cybersecurity will become a priority, with digital attacks on critical systems posing significant risks. It is estimated that by 2030 the global costs of cyber attacks could exceed US$10 billion annually. On a military level, geopolitical tensions between the United States and China could intensify. The Middle East will continue to be a focus of instability. Between 2026 and 2030, social and cultural scenarios will assume a determining role in shaping the global future. International migration will continue to be one of the most striking phenomena, driven by armed conflicts, economic inequalities and climate change. It is estimated that hundreds of millions of people may be in a situation of international or internal mobility, either in search of better living conditions or out of need for survival. Europe will face migratory pressures from Africa and the Middle East, with hundreds of thousands of people seeking refuge in countries such as Italy, Greece, Spain and Germany. This flow will require more robust integration policies, but it could also generate social and political tensions, fueling populist and nationalist discourses. In the United States, immigration will continue to be a central issue, with restrictive policies causing social tensions and protests, but also with the need for labor in sectors such as agriculture, construction and services. In Latin America, internal migration will intensify due to extreme climatic phenomena, such as floods and droughts, forcing millions of people to move from rural areas to cities. In Africa, desertification and armed conflicts in the Sahel could displace more than 20 million people, creating large-scale humanitarian crises. Urbanization will be another central phenomenon. By 2030, more than 65% of the world's population will live in urban areas, with megacities growing rapidly. Cities such as Lagos, Kinshasa, Mumbai, São Paulo and Jakarta could exceed 30 million inhabitants, facing challenges in infrastructure, housing, transport and sanitation. Accelerated urbanization will bring opportunities for economic and cultural dynamism, but also risks of inequality and social exclusion. Cities will need to invest in sustainable solutions, such as efficient public transport, affordable housing and waste management. The digitalization of cities, using smart technologies, can improve the quality of life, but will require inclusion policies to prevent vulnerable populations from being excluded. Demographic transformations will be equally decisive. Population aging in Europe, Japan and South Korea will require health and long-term care policies, with an impact on pension systems and fiscal sustainability. It is estimated that, by 2030, more than 25% of Europe's population will be over 65 years old, creating productivity and financing challenges for social systems. In contrast, Africa and parts of Asia will have growing young populations, with millions of people entering the job market. This phenomenon could be an opportunity for economic dynamism, but also a risk of instability if sufficient jobs are not created. India, for example, will have more than 1.5 billion inhabitants in 2030, with a young population that could drive growth, but will require massive investments in education and training. China will face the challenge of an aging population, with more than 400 million people over the age of 60 in 2030, which could limit economic dynamism and increase pressure on healthcare and pension systems. Cultural scenarios will also transform. Digital globalization will continue to spread cultural values ​​and practices, but also generate tensions between local traditions and external influences. Music, cinema and literature will circulate increasingly intensely, creating a hybrid global culture. However, movements asserting identity and valuing local cultures will gain strength, seeking to preserve traditions and resist cultural homogenization. Cultural diversity will be both a wealth and a challenge, requiring policies of inclusion and respect for difference. Migration, urbanization and demographic transformations will interact with environmental and technological phenomena. Cities will have to adapt to extreme weather phenomena, such as floods and heat waves, which will affect millions of people. Climate migration will become a reality, with entire populations moving due to rising sea levels and desertification. Accelerated urbanization will require technological solutions, such as smart cities and sustainable infrastructure, but also social policies to ensure inclusion. Demographic transformations will create new balances of power, with Africa and Asia gaining demographic and economic weight, while Europe and Japan will face aging challenges. In summary, the period between 2025 and 2030 can be described as a critical transition phase, in which the events of 2025 acted as catalysts for structural changes that manifested themselves in different dimensions. The global economy entered a cycle of moderate recovery, but with persistent risks. International politics was marked by polarization and geopolitical tensions, with the United States and China competing for technological and industrial leadership, and the Middle East remaining a focus of instability. The environment has revealed the urgency of the energy transition and climate adaptation, with extreme phenomena affecting millions of people. Technology has transformed economies and societies, creating opportunities and risks. Education and health required inclusive and innovative policies. Security has become a priority, with cyberattacks and digital terrorism posing significant risks. The social and cultural scenarios revealed the importance of migration, urbanization and demographic transformations. The future will depend on the ability to articulate national interests with collective responsibilities, building a balance between competitiveness and solidarity. If countries are able to invest in responsible innovation, inclusive education and energy sustainability, it will be possible to build a fairer, sustainable and inclusive future. Otherwise, the risk of prolonged stagnation and worsening inequalities will remain high. The period between 2025 and 2030 will therefore remain a decisive moment, in which humanity was called to choose between cooperation and fragmentation, between the courage to move forward and the risk of remaining a prisoner of its own contradictions.

item.title: Death | French actress Brigitte Bardot dies aged 91
item.description: Brigitte Bardot, one of the biggest stars in world cinema, passed away yesterday at the age of 91. The actress had been admitted to the hospital in the city of Toulon, in the south of France, since November. In a statement, the Brigitte Bardot Foundation announced her death with “immense sadness”, describing her as a “world-renowned actress and singer, who chose to abandon her prestigious career to dedicate her life and energy to animal welfare and her foundation”. Known for her enormous impact on cinema in the 1950s, «BB», as she was widely called in France, was an essential ingredient of French culture and quickly became an icon after her first role in Le Trou Normand (1952). Two more films followed in 1952, when she married director Roger Vadim. A year later, Bardot conquered Hollywood and the United States, and her popularity as one of the sexiest women in the world was firmly established. Brigitte Bardot continued to act in a total of 28 films over two decades and became a symbol of women's sexual liberation. However, ruthlessly “marketed” as a sexual and hedonistic symbol, Bardot ended up succumbing to the frustration of not being taken seriously as an actress and abandoned her career to dedicate herself to campaigns for animal welfare.

item.title: Cinematheque Paixão | “Battle After Battle” to see on the last day of the year
item.description: Paul Thomas Anderson's new film, “Batalha Atras de Batalha”, will be shown at Cinemateca Paixão on the last day of 2025. In January, the film schedule will include Pedro Almodóvar's latest film, “The Room Next Door” and the new film by local director Tracy Choi In a dystopian scenario that, deep down, is not so different from what we live in today, there are people like Perfidia Beverly Hills, a revolutionary woman who seeks a fairer life for everyone. Perfidia maintains a relationship with another revolutionary, Bob Anderson, with whom she has a daughter, until one day everything goes wrong and Perfidia is forced to hide from everything and everyone, leaving her daughter with her father. In between, there is a soldier who will dedicate his life to persecuting this man and his daughter. Here is the synopsis of the film “Battle After Battle”, by Paul Thomas Anderson, which in almost three hours not only tells a story but also analyzes the current times in which we live, addressing topics such as immigration, social justice, racial struggles and the utopia of a better world. It is with this film that Cinemateca Paixão closes the year 2025, with a single screening on Wednesday the 31st, starting at 7:30 pm, just in time to leave the cinema and go celebrate the arrival of 2026. But the last days of the year also hold another cinematographic “cartridge”, with the screening of “Die My Love”, shown tomorrow, starting at 7:30 pm. The first day of the year brings “Flow – À Deriva”, which won the Oscar for Best Animated Film and which tells the story of a kitten who fights for survival in a world that is changing rapidly. On January 1st you can also see “A Useful Ghost”, the first feature film by Thai director Ratchapoom Boonbunchachoke, which caused a sensation at the Cannes Film Festival, winning the Critics' Week Grand Prize. This film will be shown again on the 4th, 10th and 14th of January. Almodóvar in English Cinemateca Paixão's program for January, entitled “Encantos de Janeiro”, also features the most recent film by Spanish director Pedro Almodóvar, and also his first film in English. “The Room Next Door” stars Julianne Moore and Tilda Swinton in the main roles and is a film that celebrates themes such as friendship, the meaning of life and euthanasia. The story begins when one of the women, upon learning that she suffers from a terminal illness, decides to take refuge in a house and ask a longtime friend to take care of her until the inevitable end. The public also has a session available on January 10th. On January 3rd, Cinemateca Paixão shows the documentary “Four Trails”, by director Robin Lee, which is a celebration of the nature that Hong Kong has in addition to the hustle and bustle of the city. This is the true story of Andre Blumberg, who in 2012 set himself the challenge of doing Hong Kong's four long-distance trails in just 72 hours, which translates into 298 kilometers. It is one of the most difficult marathons in the world, called the Hong Kong Four Trails Ultra Challenge. Tracy Choi's new Another major highlight of Cinemateca Paixão for the first days of the new year is the possibility of seeing the new film by local director Tracy Choi. “Girlfriends” will be shown on the 6th and 24th of January, after the film had its world premiere at the Busan International Film Festival, as part of the “Vision Asia” section. Elizabeth Tang, the film's actress, was nominated for the Best Supporting Actress award at the 62nd Golden Horse Awards, Taiwan's film awards. “Girlfriends” is about a girl who becomes a woman through three love stories set at the age of 17, 22 and 34, when she already has another maturity. It is a journey in search of love. Tracy Choi has had an acclaimed career in cinema since releasing “Sisterhood”, her first feature film.

item.title: Music | Colégio Moderno Orchestra live at Our Lady of Fátima Church
item.description:
On the 29th, the Colégio Moderno orchestra performs in Macau at the Church of Our Lady of Fátima, followed by a concert, on the 3rd of January, with the Macau Youth Orchestra. Pianist Adriano Jordão, founder of the Macau International Music Festival, highlights the importance of sharing music between the two orchestras
After a summer of intense musical sharing in Lisbon, the Macau Youth Orchestra and the Colégio Moderno orchestra are preparing to perform in Macau in the coming weeks. On the 29th at 8pm, the Church of Our Lady of Fátima hosts the “Concerto do Colégio Moderno”, performed by the orchestra group from the school founded in 1936. Then, on the 3rd of January, it is the turn of the two groups to take the stage at the Macau Cultural Center for the “Macau New Year Concert 2026”. Pianist Adriano Jordão, founder of the Macau International Music Festival (FIMM), has been following the partnership between the two groups and the work done by the Colégio Moderno group. The musician highlights to HM what can be heard at the concert on December 29th: the composition “Stabat Mater”, by Giovanni Battista Pergolesi, which was part of the program of the first edition of FIMM. “It has a symbolic side, because it was the performance at the first International Music Festival, in 1987. It was done to close the festival, so there is a psychological side to the repetition of this work”, he highlighted. “All of this was my idea, a little nostalgia doesn’t hurt”, added Adriano Jordão. “This is a work with all the characteristics to be done within a church, and it also has this symbolic side that is very important to me.” “Stabat Mater” is a sung prayer, central to a concert program lasting around an hour, designed for “a relatively small group of instrumentalists, with two soloists”. Adriano Jordão highlights the great enthusiasm of the members of the Colégio Moderno orchestra regarding the trip to Macau. "I see the kids' excitement about going to Macau, there is always a fascination with the East, as is evident. And I see the historical interest that all of this has, particularly for Portugal. There really is a cultural interest in maintaining a Portuguese brand in Macau, which is Chinese territory. [These concerts] serve to accelerate these cultural links." Quality work It is not the first time that Adriano Jordão has collaborated with the Macau Youth Orchestra, which in the summer of this year was in Portugal for joint performances with the group from Colégio Moderno. Colégio Moderno was founded in 1936 by João Soares, father of Mário Soares, former President of the Portuguese Republic, now deceased, himself a figure closely linked to Macau. This time, Isabel Soares, current director of Colégio Moderno, will be present in the territory for the concerts. Although the Portuguese school orchestra group has been in existence for more years than the formation of the local youth orchestra, this does not invalidate the quality of both projects, and some challenges were faced in bringing this group to Macau. "It is always difficult to take a group of people [for a trip of this type], and it is necessary to find the financial resources on one side and the other. This was done with private support and it was achieved. I am very happy that young people from Macau have made such a good impression in Portugal. I hope that this good figure is now reciprocal on this trip to Macau." The Macau Youth Orchestra considers, in a statement, that the exchange and collaboration of Isabel Soares and Adriano Jordão, accompanying the Colégio Moderno orchestra, represents “a concrete demonstration of the Macau Youth Orchestra's ongoing commitment to promoting international cultural exchange”. The concerts in question also constitute “a new page in Sino-Portuguese cultural exchange, particularly in musical exchange between young people from China and Portugal”, it is said. Asked about the importance of FIMM nowadays, Adriano Jordão did not fail to remember that what “seemed like a crazy idea at the time” actually had legs to walk on. "There was strictly nothing in Macau, in cultural terms: there was no cultural center, and the first things [shows] that were done were in a sports hall. There were no resources, there was no Macau orchestra. Everything was done from scratch and to see that, years later, it was worth doing... I was at the last edition, last year, and I was impressed to see that a great artistic quality was maintained", he concluded.

item.title: IC | Helena Almeida's first solo exhibition in Asia arrives in 2026
item.description: The year 2026 Macau hosts a major exhibition on Portuguese artist Helena Almeida. “Helena Almeida: I’m Here – Presença and Resonance” is scheduled to take place at the beginning of the year, being the artist’s first major solo exhibition in Asia. The Macau Museum of Art also presents works by Chinese artists interacting with the work of Helena Almeida The Government announced this Thursday the opening of an exhibition of Chinese artists, invited to interact with the work of Helena Almeida (1934-2018), in anticipation of the Portuguese artist's first major solo exhibition in Asia. “Helena Almeida: I’m Here – Presença and Resonance” will open at the beginning of 2026, with around 42 sets made up of 190 pieces by the Portuguese artist, according to the statement. In the note, the Cultural Institute (IC) also announced that the exhibition “Resonância – Corpo. Objecto. Reflexão”, marked by Chinese artists' interpretations of the Portuguese artist's work, will be on display at the Macau Art Museum from December 19th to April 26th. The exhibition brings together “recently commissioned works” by six artists from Macau and mainland China, invited “to foster a dialogue that transcends time and space” with Helena Almeida, said the IC. You can see drawings by Erica Min Han, a Chinese artist based in London, which “continue Helena Almeida’s reflection on the presence of the body”. In turn, the work by the Chinese Gao Fuyan “A Grade of the Mind”, embroidered with hair on paper, “remotely mirrors Helena Almeida's concept of the body as an instrument”, said the IC. Also Chinese, Sun Xiaoyu “adopts Helena Almeida’s blue to expand the visual dialogue about existence and its borders through the oriental aesthetic practice of dissolving the self in the object”, the note states. The IC highlighted that this exhibition aims to “strengthen the exchange of contemporary art” and the “cultural dialogue” between China and Portugal, paving the way for the great retrospective. A full life Born in Lisbon in 1934, Helena Almeida created, from the 1960s onwards, a multifaceted work that stood out for its self-representation, reflecting on the tension relationships between the body, space and the work. He used the body as a support and creative object, using painting, photography, engraving, installation and video. Helena Almeida studied painting at the Escola Superior de Belas-Artes in Lisbon, beginning to exhibit individually in 1967, at Galeria Buchholz. One of the artists who marked her journey was Lucio Fontana, and initially Helena Almeida even exhibited torn canvases similar to this artist's work, “canvases with the back facing forward, thus showing what was traditionally facing the wall”, describes Joana Simões Henriques regarding an exhibition with works by Helena Almeida recently held at the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation museum, in Lisbon. But from 1975 onwards the artist “began to explore other disciplines such as drawing, photography and video, seeing them as means to understand the relationship between the author's body and the space of the work”. It is here that the artist’s body becomes “the support of her art, becoming subject and object, not in the form of a self-portrait, but rather in the sense of ‘inhabiting the painting’, of placing herself within her work, of being her work”. In these works, “[Helena Almeida’s] face often appears hidden”, it is described in the same note. In 1977, the exhibition “Alternativa Zero” took place in Portugal, described as “marking in Portuguese contemporary art”, presenting “a series of photographs [by Helena Almeida] with elements attached to the image, thus creating the illusion of the work leaving its place and entering the space of the observer”, wrote Joana Simões Henriques. The artist represented Portugal at the Venice Biennale on two occasions: in 1982 and 2005, and in 2004 she participated in the Sydney Biennale, with her work being exhibited in individual and collective exhibitions in national and international museums and galleries. In 2015, he presented a traveling solo exhibition Corpus at Fundação de Serralves (2015), in Porto, in Paris (2016), in Brussels (2016) and Valencia (2017). In 2017, he also presented a solo exhibition “Work is never finished” at the Art Institute, in Chicago, in the United States. His work is present in Portuguese and international collections such as: Berardo Collection, Lisbon; Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation, Lisbon; Serralves Foundation, Porto; Hara Museum of Contemporary Art, Tokyo; Barcelona Museum of Contemporary Art; Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía, Madrid; MUDAM – Musée d’Art Moderne Grand-Duc Jean, Luxembourg; Tate Modern, London.

item.title: Analysts highlight challenges in Macau’s economic growth
item.description: Experts contacted by the Lusa agency foresee challenges in the growth of Macau's economy for 2026, with the recovery of the gaming sector contrasting with weak domestic consumption and pressure for diversification. Economist Henry Chun Kwok Lei, professor of Business Economics at the University of Macau and vice-president of the Macau Economic Association, maintains a “cautiously optimistic” outlook for 2026, predicting Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth of around 2.5 percent during the next financial year. “The high base of gross gaming revenue this year, projected between 246 and 248 billion patacas, will condition the growth potential in 2026. Even if casino revenue increases by around 4 percent, to more than 250 billion patacas, its contribution to global economic growth will decrease,” Henry Lei told Lusa. Ben Lee, a consultant for gaming activity in Southeast Asia, has a more positive outlook. “Gross gaming revenue has already reached 226.5 billion patacas by November this year, so it is more than likely that we will exceed the projection of 228 billion,” he said. The estimate for game revenue for 2026, the analyst added, is “a little conservative”. “Unless we go back next year, based on the current situation, gross revenues could reach a value between 260 and 270 billion patacas by the end of 2026”, he estimated. Alarms sounded The forecast included in the Budget for 2025 pointed to total revenues of around 240 billion patacas, but the weak start of the year, especially after the tariff war triggered by the USA, raised alarms among the economic team of Sam Hou Fai's Executive, which approved in June an Amending Budget in which it cut 4.56 billion patacas in the revenue forecast, highly dependent on the gaming sector (around 83 percent of Macau's GDP). The Macau Economic Association predicts that annual GDP growth in 2025 will be around 5.4 percent, an estimate based on the “stable and positive trend of the main indicators of economic development, the globally stable functioning of the budgetary and financial systems and the maintenance of low unemployment rates”. As for next year, adds the association, “the Macau economy is expected to maintain a stable and positive trajectory”, although the global panorama “continues to be characterized by interconnected turbulence and complexity”. The Government Budget for 2026 points to a 3.5 percent increase in Macau casino revenues next year, reaching 236 billion patacas, still the highest value since the pandemic. Other critical challenges that Macau faces in 2026 are stimulating local consumption and supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Speaking to Lusa, Lei Choek Kuan, president of the Federation of Industry and Commerce of Macau, pointed to the “irreversible” change in consumption patterns underway and highlighted the importance of government support for companies to maintain confidence. Economist Henry Lei advocates a deeper structural transformation that goes beyond subsidies and suggested that local SMEs should look for differentiation and premium services — such as “improving after-sales service, developing creative cultural products and creating high-end culinary experiences” — to serve a niche demographic with high purchasing power, rather than competing on price with Mainland China.

item.title: CPSP | Officer drives drunk, has accident and flees the scene
item.description: The 31-year-old police officer tested the balloon and found 1.88 grams of alcohol per liter of blood. In addition to criminal liability, the CPSP initiated disciplinary proceedings against the agent An officer from the Public Security Police Corps (CPSP) is being subject to disciplinary proceedings for driving drunk, crashing his vehicle into a flowerbed and fleeing the scene. The incident happened in the early hours of December 24, when the 31-year-old man was off duty, and is therefore being investigated for the crimes of driving while drunk and evading responsibility. According to authorities, the case was detected in the early hours of December 24, when the police were called to the intersection between Rua da Barca and Rua de João de Araújo, after a vehicle crashed into a flower bed. The result was a scene of destruction that did not miss metal posts and a flowerbed. After identifying the vehicle involved in the accident, authorities approached the off-duty officer, who appeared to have a strong smell of alcohol. Suspicions that were confirmed by the balloon test, which showed a result of 1.88 grams of alcohol per liter of blood. Furthermore, the detainee's vehicle had been parked illegally. The case was forwarded to the Public Prosecutor's Office, and the agent is charged with the crimes of driving while intoxicated, which carries a sentence of up to 1 year in prison, and evading responsibility, which carries a prison sentence of up to 1 year. Alarm ringing The fact that the suspect was a CPSP agent meant that the accident merited a police reaction, via the security department's website. “The CPSP deeply regrets the case of drunk driving by a police officer, reiterating that it has always given great importance to the disciplinary behavior of its personnel” was published. The CPSP also guaranteed that the acts of agents “that violate the law and discipline are treated severely and in accordance with the law”. In addition to criminal liability, the CPSP opened a disciplinary investigation on the same day “to implement disciplinary liability in accordance with the law”. In response to the incident, it is stated on the Secretary for Security's portal that “all departments received immediate instructions to continuously reinforce the awareness and education of their subordinate officers, reminding officers that their personal conduct is linked to the positive image of the police force”. It was also highlighted that even when officers are “off duty” they must “maintain the highest standards of self-discipline and comply with laws and regulations”.

item.title: L’Arc | SJM obtains authorization for direct exploration
item.description: The concessionaire, SJM Resorts, obtained authorization to operate the Casino L’Arc Macau, under the form of direct management and exploitation, from 2am on December 30th. The announcement was made by the Gaming Inspection and Coordination Directorate (DICJ) and was expected after an agreement for the acquisition of the casino by the concessionaire was announced. “Taking into account that the three-year ‘transitional period’ granted to ‘satellite casinos’ ends at the end of the current year, SJM submitted a request to cease operating Casino L’Arc Macau as a “satellite casino” from 01:59 on 30 December, which was authorized by the Macao SAR Government”, it was stated. “After analysis and consideration, the Macao SAR Government considered that the request meets the requirements and conditions of the respective legislation, and therefore granted authorization to the aforementioned request”, it was added. The DICJ also promises to monitor the operation of the casino.

item.title: Real Estate | Drop in birth rate linked to crisis
item.description: The president of Centaline Property Agency, Shih Wing-ching, considers that the drop in the birth rate is one of the factors that is contributing to the reduction in the value of real estate. The position was taken in an interview with am730 station, cited by Macau News Agency. According to Shih, in the last five years the price of housing in Macau has decreased by 40 percent, largely driven by the birth rate, currently 0.68 children per woman. Therefore, he appealed to the authorities to ease immigration policies, so that the price recovers again. "The continued decline has depleted residents' confidence. Even buyers are hesitant to enter the market, fearing losses in asset values," he said. The official also admitted that the Government is not exactly concerned, despite the buyers' losses: “They thought that lower house prices were not necessarily a bad thing, and that young people could thus enter the real estate market — a situation that could help with social stability, with fewer complaints”, he added.

item.title: Tai Fung Bank | Fitch reduces financial viability rating
item.description: The performance of loans linked to the real estate market in Mainland China is highlighted by the rating agency as the main factor for reducing the rating to the “bb” level. The assessment on the debt issuance was maintained at “BBB+” The financial rating agency Fitch reduced Banco Tai Fung's financial viability rating from “bb+” to “bb”, warning of the possible impact of unexpected events on the institution's survival. The change was announced last week and justified by the impact of loans to the Mainland China real estate market on the bank's financial performance. The “bb” level is the fifth highest on the 10-level financial viability rating scale, but indicates the existence of “high vulnerability” in the bank’s viability, if there are “unexpected changes in long-term commercial or economic conditions”. The change in the financial viability rating comes despite Fitch recognizing that there are “moderate” expectations of the bank's continued viability and “strong financial strength”, linked to the fact that Banco Tai Fung is owned by the Bank of China. However, loans linked to the property market in Mainland China are a concern. Fitch indicates that at the end of the first half of this year, loans represented 22 percent of the bank's total assets, an exposure considered “above the banking system average of 15 percent”. “We predict that the real estate market will take time to recover, prolonging the bank’s financial recovery”, indicated the agency. In negative terms, Fitch also highlights the lower quality of the bank's assets, because the rate of non-performing loans remains “too high”, at 15.8 percent of the total of these loans. The default rate is also highlighted as a factor in the significant reduction of the bank's profits, not only due to the loans that remain unpaid, but also because the market will have a lower demand for loans, which has been one of the supports of the institution's commercial model. Support from above Despite the challenges, the bank has in its favor the fact that it is owned by the Bank of China, which analysts believe is ready to inject money into Tai Fung. The connection with the Bank of China means that the assessment on the debt issuance is maintained at “BBB+”, the fourth highest level of the 11 that constitute the rating. The Chinese state bank has a higher rating than Tai Fung in terms of debt issuance rating. Given this difference, Fitch admits an upward revision of Tai Fung's level, if there are signs that the Bank of China is ready to inject capital into the institution founded by Ho Yin. In terms of Tai Fung's operating environment, Fitch highlights that it is the fourth largest bank in Macau, measured by loan value, where gaming is expected to continue to drive economic growth.

item.title: Unemployment | Global and resident rates unchanged
item.description: The Statistics and Census Services Directorate (DSEC) revealed that the unemployment rate, in global terms, was 1.7 percent between the months of September and November; while the unemployment rate for residents stood at 2.3 percent over the same period. According to a statement from DSEC, these are the same rates compared to the months of August to October this year. DSEC highlights that the number of unemployed residents was 6,700, with the majority of those looking for work “previously working in the retail trade and lotteries and other gambling sectors”. Also noteworthy is a 0.5 percent increase in residents looking for their first job, a category that represents 14.4 percent of unemployed people with resident status, also in the months of September to November. Another figure announced concerns the number of underemployed residents, 5,900, “noting that the majority belonged to the sector of real estate activities and services provided to companies, the transport and storage sector and the retail sector”. According to preliminary estimates from migration records, the average number of MSAR residents and non-resident workers, who worked in the MSAR but lived abroad, was estimated to be around 109,300 in the reference period. The total workforce, made up of these individuals and the active population living in the Macao SAR (385,600), was 494,900 people, 2,700 more than in the previous period.

item.title: Airport | Chan Chak Mo's company wins competition
item.description: The Bright Luck Gourmet Company, which is part of the Future Bright group, controlled by former deputy Chan Chak Mo, won the public tender to supply meals to SEMAC, the company responsible for airport security. The information was released by the Department of Supervision and Management of Public Assets. According to data from the public tender, Bright Luck Gourmet presented a proposal of 31 patacas per meal for workers, for a total of 6.8 million patacas. The same conditions were presented by the Hua Feng Restoration Management Services Society, which was passed over. In addition to these two proposals, there was a third from the company Ou Leong Food Products Factory that was not accepted. Ou Leong had a proposal of 35 patacas per meal.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negociar o quê? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the yardstick of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English.
